title.narrative: CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa
CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa

description.narrative: Insatsens "Klimatförändringar Budget och Finansiering i Afrika" mål är att stödja Afrikanska regeringar i att integrera responsen på klimatförändringarna i sina ordinarie budget- och planeringsprocesser. Detta uppnås genom dialogarbete och fallstudier, stödja regeringarna i att utforma och genomföra publik finansiell förvaltning (Public Finance Management, PFM) och att stödja reformarbete som bidrar till transparens och ansvarsfullhet. Programmets övergripande mål är att reducera klimatförändringarnas effekter och att öka motståndskraften i Afrikas länder samt att stödja regeringar i Afrika att utnyttja möjligheterna för nå en rättvis övergång till noll kolutsläpp och för att minska koldioxidutsläppen .Afrikas förhandlingsposition enligt Parisavtalet förväntas stärkas genom programmet och bidra till ökade finansieringsmöjligheter för åtgärder till klimatanpassning. CABRI ( Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspart. Partner är UNDP (United Nations Developmment Programmes), IIED (International Institute Environmental Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Den totala projektbudgeten är 12 800 000 SEK för en förstudie för ett år. Programmet är femårigt i sin implementering fas och Sida stödjer en ettårig förstudieperiod. Den Pan- Afrikanska institutionen CABRI (The Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspartner. CABRI´s samarbetspartner är UNDP, IIED (International Institution for Environment and Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Detta är en förstudie på ett år vilken ska förbereda en efterföljande implementeringsfas på fyra år. Programmet har tre komponenter: 1) Syd- syd lärande avseende att integrera klimatförändrings insatser i budgetprocesser. Denna komponent leds av CABRI. CABRI ska också utveckla en webbaserad portal och ett nätverk av experter samt koordinera insatsen i sin helhet. 2) Landbaserat stöd till utvalda länder i form av teknisk assistans till regeringar och statliga myndigheter som arbetar med åtgärder för klimatförändringar och att integrera dessa i ländernas budget processer. Detta arbete leds av UNDP 3) Klimatfinansiering och förvaltning vilket ska stärka översynen, transparensen och ansvarsfullheten bland aktörerna. Detta arbete leds av IIED och IBP.

The primary objective of the Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa (IBFCCA) is to integrate Climate Change into the budget process. CABRI is requesting 1 247 738 USD for an inception phase of 12 months. 30 000 USD will be commissioned by Sida for an external Management and Control audit. The planned programme is for another four years. The Pan African institution, the Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative, CABRI will be Sida´s agreement partner and take the lead working closely with key implementing partners; UNDP, IIED International Institution for Environment and Development and IBP (International Budget Partnership). The inception phase aims to prepare the Implementation Phase securing effectiveness and funding. The design of the Implementation Phase will aim to integrate gender fully into the programme and define specific gender-related initiatives. The program has three components: 1)South-South learning on integrating CC in fiscal and budget planning will be led by the Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative (CABRI), who will also support a web-based resource and a cadre of related expertise and provide overall coordination. 2) Country-based work will support the government institutions involved in CC integration in two countries, with technical assistance from UNDP. 3) Climate finance governance work will strengthen oversight, transparency and accountability actors and practices and will be led by the International Budget Partnership (IBP) and International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED). The programme will respond to a demand from governments and theirs increasing interest for budget tagging flows mechanism to see the effectivity and efficiency of current allocated budget of Climate Change spending. The IBFCCA programme will enhance and foster capacity building of the African regional institutions and the national governments to better access climate finance. Relevance to Sweden´s Development Cooperation Strategy for Sub-Saharan Africa: The proposal falls in the category of support area 1, sub -support area 1.2; Strengthened capacity of regional actors to work towards increased resilience against climate change and natural disasters, including capacity for food security. It focuses on Ministries of Finance to become involved in climate policy and to mobilise the wider national and local budgetary process involving government, legislatures and civil society. The Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) are key. NDCs embody efforts by each country to reduce national emissions and adapt to the impacts of climate change.

This is an inception phase (one year) of a wider another four year implementation programme. The wider objectives (full programme) are reduced CC impact with a gender focus and a reduced adaptation gap and promoting opportunities for just transition to low carbon economy. Immediate impact, institutional support: Reform and strengthening of the budget process of countries MoFs, strengthened pan-African negotiating position, empowered CSOs and accontability actors. Further potential impacts are increased levels of CC and gender expenditure public/private, increased effectiveness of expenditure through improved Climate Change Impact Assessment. Outcomes by components respectively: Component A (CABRI) Active liaison officials/champions, African CC/Gender integration effective and networks working on CC Gender Integration. Component B (UNDP) Government approval of country review, government approval of pilot reform. Component C (IIEED/IBP) Climate Finance Accountability (CFA) by governments, state and non-state Accountability Actors, Engagement in peer exchange and Workshops in strengthening Climate Finance Assessment. Ouptputs starting during inception phase: Component A: case studies, peer exchange events, pilot IBFCCA portal, CC/Gender integration cadre operation.There will be four peer exchange and learning events during the Inception Phase, two of which will be led by CABRI under Component A. The third will be organized jointly by CABRI and IBP/IIED, with IBP/IIED organizing the preparation and CABRI organizing the actual peer exchange and learning event. The fourth will be organized jointly by CABRI and UNDP, again with UNDP organizing the preparation and CABRI organizing the event. Two specific reports will be prepared to inform the preparation of the Implementation Phase, one related to gender and the other to Covid. These reports will be self-standing and may be attached as annexes or working papers to the Implementation Phase Document. B: Country reviews differnt methods as CPEIR (CC Public Expenditure and Institutional Review), CCFF (Climate Change Financial Framework), CCIA (Climate Change Impact Assessment) CC tagging. This component will support two country actions in the Inception Phase: the first will be a country review and the second will support piloting a new budget/finance practice. The work will use the methods developed by UNDP Kenya and other relevant ones, with technical and financial support from UNDP Regional Service Centre for Africa, and the extensive experience of the UNDP Regional Hub in Bangkok over the last 8 years. The activities undertaken will be selected and led by country governments. C: Country CFA (Climate Finance Accountability). The Inception Phase will involve a structured programme of capacity building for partner CSOs in 2 of the 4 focus countries (i.e. Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius and Mozambique). IBP and IIED already have some good working relationships with possible partners which will facilitate a rapid start to activities and minimise the constraints caused by the need to work remotely. The collaboration will be based primarily around the preparation of Climate Finance Accountability (CFA) Assessments for each country. The CFAs will provide a stocktake of the current state of climate finance transparency and accountability, including the role of Accountability Actors (AAs), and the “demand side” of climate finance management, including partnerships with civil society organizations (CSOs). It will build on the joint work of the International Budget Partnership (IBP) and International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED). In addition to the stocktake, the CFAs will provide a capacity needs assessment and propose an Action Plan for improving transparency and accountability over the short, mid and long term. A direct result of the inception phase will be a four year proposal of an implementation phase. The following activities are expected to have substantial progress completed by the end of month 8 although the activities may not be completed and dissemination and approval work is unlikely to have taken place. • keynote papers and case studies for the first two peer exchange and learning (i.e. the review of African experience with integration and the gender/CC integration exchange)• two peer exchange and learning (i.e. for the review of experience with CC integration and for gender/CC integration)• the design studies for the portal and the capacity building and cadre• the country review (e.g. CPEIR/CCFF/CCIA)• the pilot reform (e.g. tagging)• the Country Climate Finance Accountability Landscape Assessments and the keynote paper for the third peer exchange and learning on CFAs.

title.narrative: COVID-19 BLIAP - Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific, Phase 3, 2020-2021
COVID-19 BLIAP- Att vara HBTQI-person i Asien och Oceanien, Fas 3, 2020-2021

description.narrative: Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018, first under the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooperation for SouthEast Asia, and then under the the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooopeation for Asia and the Pacific. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities, but from the Global Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation in the areas of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Funds of 5 msek were chanelled through the Global LGBTI partnership with USAID. In total, the Project has received 37 202 000 SEK from Sweden during 2014-2019. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. Phase 1, initiated in 2012, focused on developing an evidence base of the lived experience of LGBTI people through research and the engagement of civil society Groups throughout the region. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. 1: Legal reform and political and civic participation – The project will promote development of an enabling environment for the development and implementation of protective laws and policies that are inclusive of LGBTI people, including antidiscrimination legislation, decriminalization of homosexuality, and legal gender recognition for transgender people. 2: Access to justice, personal security and anti-violence protection – The project will promote fair and equal treatment of LGBTI persons by the justice and law enforcement systems, including improved access to justice and enhanced personalsecurity and antiviolence protection. This will include addressing hate crimes, police abuses, domestic violence and other forms of violence. 3: Health – The project will promote improved access to health and HIV services and address health disparities, including inequitable access to services, pathologization of homosexuality and transgender people, and respect for the bodily integrity of intersex people. This will include the development of policies and guidelines for health care services that are sensitive to and respectful of the health rights of LGBTI people. 4: Economic well-being – The project will promote inclusive, non-discriminatory hiring practices and equitable work environments for LGBTI people to address access to and rights violations in employment. The scope of work will extend to linkages with livelihoods and poverty alleviation programmes, particularly for the most marginalized groups within the LGBTI spectrum. 5: Education – The project will promote LGBTI people’s equitable access to an education system that is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and appropriate to the needs of the 21st century. This will include addressing harassment and bullying, inclusive curricula, and freedom of gender expression in education institutions. Efforts will include ensuring LGBTI population have access to training and education which is seeks to build 21st century skills and capacity for utilizing new technologies. The goal of the project is to promote LGBTI inclusion in Asia Pacific across five development dimensions: political and civic participation, access to justice and personal safety, economic well-being, health and education. The end-of-project outcome is: LGBTI social and economic inclusion in Asia Pacific advanced through promulgation and implementation of protective laws, policies and programmes which mitigate discrimination and violence, ensure access to LGBTI appropriate services.Three lower level or interim outcomes will contribute towards achieving the overall end of project outcome. They are: 1. Improved capacity and commitment of governments and NHRIs to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and programmes and to ensure equitable access to services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.2. Improved capacity and increased participation of LGBTI community groups in dialogue and advocacy with stakeholders – including governments, civil society, NHRIs, the private sector and youth development partners – on the development, implementation and monitoring of LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and practices as well as the promotion of equitable access to opportunities and services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.3. Improved capacity and commitment of the business sector, other private sector actors, and social protection initiatives to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive policies and programmes supporting access to employment, livelihoods, innovative social entrepreneurship and poverty alleviation. The end-of-project outcome for the previous phase of the project focused on increased capacity and willingness of rights holders and duty bearers to advocate for, develop and implement LGBTI inclusive public lawa, policies and programmes. While BLIAP´s design recoginizes the need to further develop the capacity of rights holders and duty bearers, including affording a higher priority to developing private sector partner capacity committment, this is framed within the context of a more ambitious end-of-project outcome which buold on existing foundations laid by the project to achieve an incresed number of protective laws, policies and programmes which advance LGBTI inclusion.

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five-year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. These areas of work build on the recommendations of the Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue in 2015 and the achievements of BLIA Phase 2. They also reflect the key areas of inclusion identified through a global consultative process with civil society and stakeholders on the LGBTI inclusion index in 2016. The COVID-19 has created a perfect storm of crises across the region, not just in regards to health: COVID-19 creates a socio-economic crise, disproportionately impacting already marginalized persons within societies and causing significant human rights challenges. The pandemic is disrupting the capacity of LGBTI organisations to respond to challenges, and new ways of working need to be developed. According to UNDP, the crisis also presents an opportunity for transformative change and a possibility to build back more inclusively and sustainabily. Sidas assessment is that a cost extension will allow for UNDP to continue to adapt to changing circumstances and support the LGBTI community in times of crises. It is positive that UNDP works with an expanded approach that focuses on adequate representation by young LGBTI-persons and emerging issues such as LGBTI inclusion in climate action and adaptation. This also strengthens the relevance in relation to the on-going Strategy for Regional Asia and the Pacific (2016-2021).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) är ett regionalt projekt som genomförs av UNDP. Det har tidigare beviljats medel från Sida mellan 2014–2018. År 2019 gick BLIAP in i fas 3 med genomförandeperioden 2019-2023. Fas 3 av Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) bygger på tidigare arbete och resultat i fas 1 och 2 och genomförs med fokus på fem strategiska dimensioner. Dessa arbetsområden bygger på rekommendationer från Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue under 2015 och resultaten från fas 2. De återspeglar också de områden som identifierades som viktigast att inkludera under en global konsultationsprocess med civila samhället och aktörer kring LGBTI inclusion index 2016. UNDP och Sida har haft en nära dialog kring hur COVID-19 och politisk turbulens har påverkat programmet och dess målgrupp. Att vara HBTQI i Asien och Oceanien ökar risken för marginalisering och social exkludering. COVID-19 skapar inte bara en hälsokris, utan även en socio-ekonomisk kris där redan marginaliserade grupper drabbas extra hårt. Samtidigt skapar krisen också en möjlighet att bygga tillbaka bättre på ett sätt som är mer hållbart och inkluderande, och det finns ett momentum att bygga vidare på. Genom en avtalsändring fortsätter ambassaden att stödja UNDP under 2021 som är det sista året för den regionala strategin för Asien och Oceanien. Ambassadens bedömning är att denna avtalsändring möjliggör för UNDP att fortsätta stödja den regionala HBTQI-communityn under en tid av kris. UNDP har arbetat aktivt för att anpassa stödet till den nya situationen och stöd för ökad digital säkerhet kommer också att ingå i budgeten. Strategirelevansen bedöms ha ökat genom att UNDP arbetar mer integrerat med miljö och klimat, genom att verka för ökad representation av HBTQI-personer inom klimatområdet.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer
8.8 - Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.

8.8 - Skydda arbetstagarnas rättigheter och främja en trygg och säker arbetsmiljö för alla arbetstagare, inklusive arbetskraftsinvandrare, i synnerhet kvinnliga migranter, och människor i otrygga anställningar.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Zimbabwe Urban WASH and Cholera Mitigation 2019 - 2020
COVID-19 Zimbabwe Urban WASH and Cholera Mitigation 2019 - 2020

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 The contribution "Urban WASH and Cholera Mitigation" seeks to mitigate the outbreak and spread of cholera, typhoid and other diarrheal diseases in Zimbabwe. Building on a previous programme in the previous year, the contribution will:
• Expand social mobilization of communities around the risk of cholera and Improving safe hygiene and sanitation practices, with a focus on participatory health and hygiene education in institutions (health facilities, schools) and affected communities – this may also entail provision of temporary latrines / mobile toilets where appropriate. • Distribution of WASH hygiene kits, including household water treatment chemicals to high risk areas. • Strengthening coordination and surveillance mechanisms at national and sub-national levels. • Remobilising Rapid Response teams to reach diarrhoea-impacted households within 48 hours of cases presenting at clinics as this strategy proved effective during the 2018 cholera response and extend this capacity to other Provinces as both a preparedness and response mechanism. • Further Stockpiling of hygiene kits, water treatment tablets and IEC materials. • Monitoring of program activities and water quality, quantities etc. • Rehabilitation/upgrading/construction of strategic water points with a focus of maximizing use of perennial water sources to cover needs of institutions (schools, health centres) and vulnerable communities. • Maintaining and retraining existing Community Health clubs and establishment of new Health Clubs where needed in the community, schools, health centres and market places in high-risk communities.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen "Urban WASH and Cholera Mitigation" syftar till att mildra och hindra utbrott av kolera, tyfoid och andra vattenburna sjukdomar i Zimbabwe. Utifrån förra årets programme kommer insatsen att: • Utveckla mobilisering och kunskap kring riskerna av kolera samt förbättra hygien- och sanitetsrutiner. Ett särskilt fokus kommer att ligga på hälso- och hygienutbildning för hälsofaciliteter, skolor samt i de områden och kommuner som är mest utsatta. Temporära latriner kommer eventuellt att sättas upp i dessa områden. • Så kallade “WASH hygienkits” kommer att delas ut, inklusive kemikalier för att rena vatten i högriskområden. • Stärka koordination och övervakningsmekanismer på nationell och sub-nationell nivå. • Mobilisera och stärka så kallade “Rapid Response teams” för att snabbt kunna nå ut till hushåll som är påverkade av vattenburna sjukdomar inom 48 timmar av första sjukdomsfallet. Detta har visat sig vara en effektiv strategi under kolerasresponsen 2018. • Öka lagertillgången av hygienkit, vattenbehandlingstabletter och utbildningsmaterial. • Övervakning av vattenkvalitet och programaktiviteter. • Rehabilitering och utbyggnad av strategiska vattenresurser, för att öka tillgången på rent vatten till sårbara områden samt skolor, kliniker och andra hälsocentrum. • Upprätthålla och stärka befintliga Community Health Clubs och utveckla nya sådana vid behov, särskilt vid skolor, klinker och vid marknader och andra högriskområden.

The overall objective of the programme is to provide effective WASH services to mitigate the chance of a cholera outbreak during the rainy season. The proposed interventions will focus on Household, Community and Institutional level activities over a one year period. The activities are aimed to cover: Immediate (First 3 to 6 months) Expand social mobilization of communities around the risk of cholera and Improving safe hygiene and sanitation practices, with a focus on participatory health and hygiene education in institutions (health facilities, schools) and affected communities – this may also entail provision of temporary latrines / mobile toilets where appropriate Distribution of WASH hygiene kits, including household water treatment chemicals to high risk areas Strengthening coordination and surveillance mechanisms at national and sub-national levels Remobilising Rapid Response teams to reach diarrhoea-impacted households within 48 hours of cases presenting at clinics as this strategy proved effective during the 2018 cholera response and extend this capacity to other Provinces as both a preparedness and response mechanism. Further Stockpiling of hygiene kits, water treatment tablets and IEC materials Monitoring of program activities and water quality, quantities etc. Medium (3 to 9 months) Rehabilitation/upgrading/construction of strategic water points with a focus of maximizing use of perennial water sources to cover needs of institutions (schools, health centres) and vulnerable communities Maintaining and retraining existing Community Health clubs and establishment of new Health Clubs where needed in the community, schools, health centres and market places in high-risk communities. Beyond this 12 month period, there is a need for large scale infratructure maintainence, repair and construction. This is beyond the current remit of the programme and is fundamental are for long term sustainability and is therefore noted as a major risk.

description.narrative: With the rapidly deteriorating humanitarian situation in Zimbabwe, the Embassy of Sweden requested support from the Humanitarian Unit at Sida and a nexus expert to visit the country and assess the current challenges and help the Embassy align their strategy to work more in the resilience-humanitarian nexus to maximise the impact of the Embassy's and the Sida Humanitarian Unit's investment in Zimbabwe. The concluding nexus report from Sida recognised that WASH in Zimbabwe from both a development and humanitarian point of view, was not receiving adequate financial support. The report recommended that there was a dire need to further support the development of WASH through the Embassy's development funding, aiming at longer-term WASH initiatives, whilst complementing these efforts with shorter-term emergency humanitarian funding - both through UNICEF. Sida’s Humanitarian Unit has recently taken the decision to provide direct support to UNICEF of 30 MSEK, among other things, to combat emergency WASH issues, as laid out in the country's recent Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP). This comes at a time when Zimbabwe is facing the COVID-19 crisis and humanitarian funding will be allocated to tackling the virus. This contribution, therefore, seeks to build long term WASH resilience, reducing incidences of typhoid, cholera and indirectly, COVID-19, while complimenting the emergency WASH response. Because this is a new programme, the first progress report is expected in June 2020.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNFPA Ukraine: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination 2020-2023
COVID-19 UNFPA Ukraine: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination 2020-2023

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNFPA has applied to Sida for funding of 15 400 000 SEK to carry out the "Equality springboard: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination" Project in Ukraine during the period 2020-2023.
The intervention aims at boosting the process of social norms change and withdrawal from gender stereotypes in education, at work and at home, as well as in the community life. This goal will be achieved by 1) enhancing capacities of the education system to integrate gender sensitive approach; 2) supporting men and boys’ engagement into advancing gender equality at the community level through applying equal distribution of duties in family life and participation in fathers' programs; 3) engaging corporate sector to introduce family friendly gender sensitive approaches, including domestic and gender-based violence prevention practices.
The intervention’s total budget is 15 900 000 SEK, out of which the organization’s own funding is approximately 494 000 SEK (54 000 USD).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNFPA har ansökt Sida om 15 400 000 SEK för att genomföra projektet "Equality springboard: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination" i Ukraina under perioden 2020-2023.
Insatsen syftar till att främja förändringen av sociala normer, samt att eliminera genderstereotyper inom utbildningaq, i arbetslivet, i hemmet och i samhällslivet. Målet kommer att uppnås genom 1) att öka kapaciteten inom utbildningssystemet att kunna integrera ett jämställdhet; 2) att stödja mäns och pojkars engagemang i att bidra till jämställdhet i samhället genom en jämställd arbetsfördelning i hemmet och deltagande i program för pappor; 3) att engagera näringslivet att införa arbetssätt som främjar jämställdhet, inklusive förebyggande av könsbaserat våld och våld i hemmet.
Insatsens totala budget är 15 900 000 SEK, av vilka organisationens egna medel är cirka 494 000 SEK (54 000 USD).

The overall goal of the project is to boost the process of social norms change and withdrawal from gender stereotypes in education, at work and at home and in the community life and create supportive environment and growing public demand for advancing equal rights and opportunities for women and men in Ukraine. The objectives of the Project are as follows: Objective 1. To enhance capacities of the education system to integrate gender sensitive and non-discriminative content and approach in the school curriculum, textbooks and education materials and teaching practices and to support educational practitioners to promote stereotype-free gender norms among young Ukrainian men and women; Objective 2. To support men and boys’ engagement into advancing gender equality and women’s empowerment at the community level through applying equal distribution of duties in family life, including care of their children and participation in fathers programmes; Objective 3. To engage corporate sector and provide it with guidelines and tools to introduce family friendly gender sensitive approaches in their corporate policies and programmes for staff and corporate social responsibility programmes, including domestic and gender-based violence prevention practices. Key strategies: Empower change agents networks: educators to support young women and men to grow and develop free-from-stereotypes and benefit from the equal rights and opportunities; male community leaders to demonstrate benefits and opportunities of egalitarian gender roles, equal distribution of family duties, equality in childcare and responsible fatherhood; corporate sector champions to pilot and demonstrate economic benefits of ‘family friendly’ gender sensitive corporate policies and programmes for employees. Boost grow of public demand for changing social norms and overcoming gender stereotypes through effective targeted communication and advocacy. Impact The overarching long-term impact level objective is that women, men and girls, boys are able to realize their full potential and rights free from stereotypes and violence at school, at work, at home and at the community level. This is due to more equitable gender norms and comprehensive gender-responsive family policies that are championed by private sector and government. The impact of this project will contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals as well as national development plans such as: Sustainable Development Strategy for Ukraine by 2030 and the National Action Plan on the Strategy Implementation by 2020. The project will contribute to the following longer-term outcomes: Outcome 1. Adolescents and young men and women in Ukraine benefit form modernized education system free from discrimination and gender stereotypes and promoting equal opportunities in education and career choices. Outcome 2. An increasingly supportive enabling environment created for boosting gender equality and gender-responsive family practices through public campaigns and engagement of local communities. Outcome 3. The corporate sector has improved understanding of the value of gender-responsive family policies, the link to gender equality and business outcomes. The project design assumes that these changes will continue beyond the project period as champion companies will make public, high level commitments to continue work to ensure workplaces are family friendly and companies will institutionalize these commitments through corporate policy change which will have a domino-effect on other companies. This will be complemented by work at the national level, whereby local authorities will commit to support for family friendly initiatives at the community level. The intervention will work towards the following six outputs: Output 1.1. Enhanced capacities of the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine (MoES) to integrate non-discriminative gender-sensitive approach into sectorial policies and action plans in line with international commitments on gender equality and human rights-based approach Output 1.2. Network(s) of educators as change agents strengthened, capacitated and equipped with modern tools and methods to deliver free-from-discrimination and gender stereotypes education and promote equal choices and opportunities among young people Output 2.1. Partner municipalities supported to develop and implement local crisis rooms for GBV survivors and men-engage programs and solutions to support fathers to exercise their roles at home and in childcare Output 2.2. Public campaign to unveil gender stereotypes, promote change of social norms based on gender equality and gender-responsive family developed and implemented Output 3.1 Corporate sector is sensitized on benefits of gender equality and zero tolerance to GBV Output 3.2. Corporate sector is supported in introducing and sustaining gender sensitive practices and family-responsive policies to advance gender equality and achieve a better health/life balance for women and men at work. Together, these outputs are indispensable elements of the project puzzle as they secure the impact from three different yet critical angles.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.

strategy.title: Reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2021
strategy.titleSV: Reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014-2021

description.narrative:
Sida is planning a second phase of the RMNCAH/N Health programme on reproductive, maternal, newborn, Child, adolescent health and nutrition in Zambia 2015-2019, extended up to June 2020 and with a planned additional extension up to December 2020 adjusting to COVID-19. A new programme is expected to start during the first half of 2021. The next phase will be assessed during the autumn of 2020 and will be a follow-up to Phase I but with a stronger focus on supporting high impact interventions and systems strengthening to ensure continued progress to reduce maternal and newborn deaths and the high number of teenage pregnancies and malnourished children. Community Health and adolescent SRHR will be further enhanced. In line with this and to ensure that appropriate data is available for the right type and direction of interventions, it is proposed to conduct an analysis of the recent Demographic Halth Survey 2018, DHS, from a more systematic Equity perspective. During the spring of 2019, a Mid-Term Review of the RMNCAH/N programme was conducted by Sida's Health and SRHR framework agreement consultancy firm KIT. Oe major take-away from the MTR findings was that Sida needs to better address and programme interventions and activities from an Equity perspective. This includes improved targeting based on inequities stemming from socio-economic, gender, geographic, age-related factors. The Ministry of Health has also requested more in-depth analysis to identify pockets of inequities in service provision and quality of care across the country. When the RMNCAH/N programme Phase I focused on more generalized interventions to improve service delivery, it has been assessed that it is now critical to support tailor-make interventions based on more individual capacities, contexts and needs in various districts in the provinces supported.
In 2019, WHO African regional office and Zambia's Ministry of Health published a report on Health Equity and Social Determinants of Health in Zambia to gather evidence to support a comprehensive policy move towards Universal Health Coverage in Zambia. The Zambian Government is committed to fulfil its aim to reach the SDGs Before 2030 and to "leave no one behind" - a phrase which is often heard in various policy and health-decision making fora. The Embassy has contacted the School of Public Health at the University of Zambia, SoPH, as they have been responsible for conducting a recent study of the DHS 2013/14 from a Health inequality perspective earlier in 2019, based on the WHO study. A dissemination of results took place in August 2019. As the Embassy started planning Phase II of the Health programme, SoPH were approached to consider repeating a similar study on the DHS 2018 to ensure analysis of recent data. The preliminary DHS 2018 was launched in October 2019 and the final study was published in February 2020.
The Equity analysis will estimate national and provincial level RMNCHA&N health indicators and intervention coverage levels, and examine rural-urban, gender, age and socioeconomic inequalities over the period 2014—2019 , and explore availability, accessibility, acceptability and quality of care of RMNCAH&N services in selected districts in the Sida-funded provinces in Zambia. The Equity analysis will have two phases:
1. Quantitative focus: Data Collection and selection of appropriate indicators to be measured. Analysis of national, provincial and district trends in indicators. Modelling of the factors that could explain inequities. Report ready by August 2020. 2. Qualitiative focus: Barriers and facilitators to availability, accessibility and acceptability of RMNCHA/N interventions. Final report ready by March 2021. Focus on the questions how and why.
Phase 1-2 will provide a solid backbone for formulating the new programme on RMNCAH/N Phase II and provide input for detailed targeting of districts during the Inception phase of RMNCAH/N Phase II.

Sida planerar en uppföljningsfas av det pågående programmet med fokus på kvinnors, ungdomars och barns hälsa i Zambia 2015-2019 som har förlängts till och med juni 2020 och som planeras att ytterligare förlängas till december 2020 beroende på anpassning till följd av COVID-19. Ett nytt program förväntas påbörjas under första halvan av 2021 och kommer att beredas under hösten 2020 som en uppföljning till fas I. Baserat på halvtidsöversynen som svenska ambassaden genomförde våren 2019 planeras ett starkare fokus på aktiviteter som bevisligen ger god effekt samt hälsosystemsstärkande insatser. Detta för att fortsatt stödja de framsteg som gjorts i första fasen inom minskad mödra- och barnadödlighet. Inriktning mot primärhälsovård på bynivå och ungdomars SRHR kommer att särskilt prioriteras.
För att säkerställa att planerade insatser underbyggs av relevant och korrekt hälsostatistik föreslås att genomföra en mer detaljerad analys av den senaste 5-åriga nationella hälsostudien (Demographic Health Survey, DHS, 2018) utifrån ett jämlikhetsperspektiv, en s.k jämlikhetsstudie (Equity study). Under våren 2019 genomfördes en halvtidsöversyn av hälsoprogrammet av det ramavtalsupphandlade konsultföretaget KIT. En huvudsaklig slutsats från översynen var att Sida kan och bör tillämpa ett bredare jämlikhetsperspektiv i hälsostödet. Detta innebär att lägga större vikt vid insatser som syftar till att utjämna skillnader baserade på exempelvis socioekonomiska faktorer, könstillhörighet, geografi, ålder etc. Hälsoministeriet har också efterfrågat en mer djupgående analys för att identifiera delar av landet där skillnader i service och kvalitet på vården är särskilt iögonfallande. De första fyra åren av hälsoprogrammet har fokuserat på breda och omfattande insatser för att förbättra tillgång och kvalitet på vård. Ambassaden bedömer att en uppföljningsfas bör inriktas på verksamhet som är mer skräddarsydd och anpassad för lokal kontext och behov.
År 2019 publicerade WHO: s regionala kontor och det zambiska hälsoministeriet en rapport om ojämlikhet och sociala faktorer bakom hälsa för att uppnå universell tillgång till hälsa i Zambia (Universal Health Coverage). Den zambiska regeringen har åtagit sig att uppfylla ambitionen att nå de globala hållbarhetsmålen före 2030 och att "leave no one behind" - en fras som ofta hörs i politiska sammanhang. School of Public Health vid universitetet i Zambia, SoPH, ligger bakom en nypublicerad studie om skillnader i hälsa och tillgång på vårdservice baserad på DHS 2013/14, kopplat till WHO:s studie. När ambassaden påbörjade planeringen av fas II i hälsoprogrammet kontaktades SoPH för att utröna möjligheten att göra en liknande analys av DHS 2018 för att studera färskare hälsodata. Den preliminära DHS 2018 lanserades i oktober 2019 och den slutliga studien publicerades i februari 2020.
Jämlikhetsstudien kommer att analysera indikatorer på nationell- och provinsnivå och särskilt granska landsbygds-, köns-, ålders- och socioekonomiska ojämlikheter under perioden 2014—2019, samt utforska tillgänglighet, acceptans och kvalitet på vård av kvinnor, barn och ungdomar i utvalda distrikt i de Sida-finansierade provinserna i Zambia. Jämlikhetsstudien kommer att ha två faser:
1. Kvantitativt fokus: Insamling av data och val av lämpliga indikatorer som ska mätas samt analys av indikatorer och vårdutbud utifrån ett jämlikhetsperspektiv. Modellering av förklaringar bakom ojämlikhet kommer att presenteras. Rapport klar i augusti 2020. 2. Kvalitativt fokus: Utmaningar och hinder avseende tillgänglighet och acceptans av sjukvården kommer att genomföras med en slutlig rapport i mars 2021. Fokus på varför och hur-frågor i dataanalysen.
Båda faserna kommer att ge ambassaden underlag för framtagandet av ett nytt hälsoprogram och bidra till en mer detaljerad programinriktning under hälsoprogrammets inledningsfas.

Stöd till Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights
Support to Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att bidra till att stärka respekten för de mänskliga rättigheterna, att förebygga och stoppa kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna i samband med den pågående politiska och sociala krisen i Bolivia.
Projektet syftar även att säkerställa en långvarig närvaro av OHCHR i Bolivia genom att ge kontinuitet i den nuvarande utplaceringen (november och december 2019) av Mänskliga Rättighetersspecialister i landet med avsikt och stärka FNs kapacitet i landet för att tillgodose de aktuella behoven under de kommande månaderna (januari till augusti 2020). Detta kommer att bana väg för en längre engagemang i landet, som kommer att innehålla en del av tekniskt bistånd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och förstärkning av viktiga nationella institutioner enligt Högkommissariatens mandat.
På kort sikt kommer OHCHR att stärka sin kapacitet att i Bolivia genomföra övervakning och rapportering, i syfte att tala ut offentligt och oberoende om kränkningar av mänskliga rättigheter, samarbeta med myndigheter och andra aktörer samt identifiera luckor för att bygga framtida samarbetslinjer med institutioner och civilsamhällets organisationer.
OHCHR kommer också att ha kontakter med sociala och politiska aktörer på högsta nivå för att spela en nyckelroll som en oberoende instans, vars insatser kan vara värdefulla under diskussionerna mellan politiska och sociala aktörer.
OHCHR kommer att spela en viktig roll som opartisk observatör av mänskliga rättigheter i landet.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This project aims to contributing to strengthening the respect and protection for human rights in the context of the on-going political and social crisis in Bolivia, to help prevent and halt human rights violations. It will ensure a sustained UN High Commissiorner for Human Rights (OHCHR) presence in Bolivia, by giving continuity to the current deployment (November and December 2019) and strengthen its capacities to meet current needs in the coming months (January to August 2020).
This will pave the way for a longer engagement strategy in the country, which will include a component of technical assistance, capacity building and strengthening of key institutions according to the High Commissioner’s mandate. In the short term, OHCHR will strengthen its capacity to carry out monitoring and reporting, with the aim to speak out publicly and independently on human rights violations, engage with authorities and other actors as well as identify gaps to build future lines of cooperation with institutions and civil society organisations.
OHCHR will also liaise with social and political actors at the highest level, to play a key role as an independent instance, whose inputs can be valuable during the discussions amongst political and social actors.
OHCHR will also play an important role as an independent observator in the country.
-

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Rädda Barnen har ansökt om finansiering av egeninsats om 2,653,872 SEK för EU-projektet "Integrated Protection, Nutrition, Education, MHPSS and Basic Needs Programming responding to urgent life-saving needs of conflict-affected populations in North East Syria" under 2020.
Insatsen syftar till att:
1. "Address primary needs of the most vulnerable populations in a timely, effective and efficient manner".
2. "Provide integrated protection, nutrition, education, MHPSS and Basic Needs Programming responding to urgent life-saving needs of conflict-affected populations in Northeast Syria".
Rädda Barnen kommer att arbeta i samverkan med en lokal partnerorganisation, Al Salam. Rädda Barnen har det övergripande ansvaret för projektets implementering och koordinering.
Den aktuella insatsen har EU-kommissionens referensnummer ECHO/SYR/BUD/2020/91003. Insatsen har en total budget på 2 555 556 EUR, vilket motsvarar cirka 26 538 682 SEK. Av detta har Rädda Barnen beviljats 2 300 000 EUR från EU-kommissionen och ansöker om 2 653 872 SEK (cirka 10 %) från Sida.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Rädda Barnen (Save the Children Sweden) has applied to Sida for funding of 1,844,340 SEK to carry out the EU-Project "Integrated Protection, Nutrition, Education, MHPSS and Basic Needs Programming responding to urgent life-saving needs of conflict-affected populations in North East Syria" during 2020.
The project aims to:
1. "Address primary needs of the most vulnerable populations in a timely, effective and efficient manner".
2. "Provide integrated protection, nutrition, education, WASH, MHPSS and Basic Needs Programming responding to urgent life-saving needs of conflict-affected populations in Northeast Syria".
Rädda Barnen will collaborate with one local partner organisation, Al Salam. Rädda Barnen has the overall responsibility for the coordination and implementation of the project.
The contribution has the EU Commission reference number ECHO/SYR/BUD/2020/91003. The contribution's total budget is 2 555 556 EUR , which corresponds to approximately 26 538 682 SEK. The requested support from Sida is 2 653 872 SEK, which corresponds to 10 % of the total budget.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Programstöd till UN Womens landprogram
COVID-19 UN Women Strategic Note for DRC

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Ambassaden har sedan juli 2019 stöttat UN Womens landkontor med en övergångsfinansiering för slutfasen av deras strategiska plan för 2014-2018 som förlängdes för 2019. Intentionen var att efter det stödet ge långsiktigt stöd för den nya strategiska planen 2020-2024 och nu har UN Women därför ansökt om finansiering från ambassaden för den kommande femårsperioden.
UN Womens globala mål som organisation är att åstadkomma jämställdhet och stärka kvinnors egenmakt. Den strategiska planen för 2020-2024 speglar detta mål och innehåller UN Womens plan för hur de ska stödja den kongolesiska regeringen och det civila samhället och andra berörda aktörer att genomföra, övervaka och rapportera om DRK:s åtaganden om jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt. Strategiplanens fokusområden är samhällsstyrning och kvinnors politiska deltagande; kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt; utrota våld mot kvinnor; samt fred, säkerhet och humanitärt stöd.
Den totala budgeten för hela strategiperioden är 41 583 956 dollar. Sverige åtar sig genom detta beslut att stödja implementeringen av den strategiska planen med 5 miljoner SEK per år för de tre första åren. Kontrakt skrivs dock för hela perioden och intentionen är att ge ekonomiskt stöd även för de sista två åren men att omfattningen ska beslutas efter utvärdering av UN Womens arbete under de första åren. UN Women har i nuläget inte finansiering för hela budgeten. Andra stora givare är Kanada, Japan, Italien, Nederländerna och Tyskland som alla ger stöd till specifika projekt. Sverige är i nuläget den enda givaren som stöder landprogrammet med icke-öronmärkt stöd.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy has since July 2019 supported UN Women's DRC office with a bridging for the final, extended, year of their Strategic Note for 2014-2018, extended to cover 2019. The intention was to continue with a long-term support for the new Strategic Note 2020-2024. UN Women has therefore applied to the Embassy for financial support for the coming five-year period.
The global goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women. The Strategic Note for 2020-2024 is developed in that spirit and contains UN Women's plan for supporting the Congolese government and the civil society and other actors to implement, monitor, and report on the Congolese commitment regarding gender equality and women's empowerment. The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: Governance and Women's political participation; Women's economic empowerment; Ending violence against women; and Peace, security and humanitarian action.
The total budget for the five years of the Strategic Note is 41 583 956 USD. Sweden commits with this decision to support the implementation of the Strategic Note with 5 million SEK per year during the first three years. The agreement will however cover the complete strategy period and the intention is to provide financial support also for the last two years. The size of this contribution will be decided upon after assessment of UN Women's work during the first couple of years. UN Women has not at the moment secured funds for the total budget. Other large donors are Canada, Japan, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany, who are all funding specific projects. Sweden is the only donor providing non-earmarked core support.

The general goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women globally. All interventions, including in DRC, are based on this goal and UN Women DRC has formulated its vision accordingly: "An inclusive, peaceful, and prosperous Democratic Republic of Congo, where women, girls, boys and men are free and secured, enjoy equal rights, and have equal opportunities to access a better life, to make their own decisions to improve their living conditions in order to achieve sustainable peace, security, the respect of human rights and women's rights for the attainment of sustainable development goals" The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: 1) Governance and Women's political participation; 2) Women's economic empowerment; 3) Ending violence against women; 4) Peace, security and humanitarian action. Building on these priority areas, the Strategic Note has the following strategic impact areas and specific outcomes and outputs of the development results framework. Each strategic area outcome has a theory of change and is aligned with the outputs in the UN Women Global Strategic Plan as well as the UNSDCF outcomes. 1. Governance and Women Political Participation Outcome 1.1: By 2024, public institutions, the media and civil society, at both central and decentralized levels, effectively exercise their roles for a peaceful, effective and inclusive democratic governance that is conducive to citizen participation and the strengthening of the rule of law. Outcome 1.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC, more specifically the most vulnerable (women, children, refugees and displaced people) will enjoy their human rights, in particular equitable access to justice (including juvenile justice), legal identity and protection, through strengthening judicial and security systems, the monitoring capacities of civil society organizations on human rights and institutional accountability. 2. Women’s economic empowerment Outcome 2.1: By 2024, Congolese people are enjoying sustainable inclusive economic growth driven by agricultural transformation, economic diversification open to innovation and the promotion of young women's entrepreneurship Outcome 2.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC benefit from inclusive social protection and a demographic dividend driven by demographic control and the empowerment of young people and women 3. Ending violence against women Outcome 3. Populations, especially the most vulnerable, enjoy equitable, quality and sustainable access to basic social services, including HIV/AIDS. 4. Peace, security and humanitarian action Outcome 4.1: By 2024, the prevalence of violence and armed conflict is reduced and the security of people and property is improved, especially for vulnerable people, including refugees/displaced persons, women and young people. Outcome 4.2: By 2024, humanitarian organizations and government humanitarian organizations are providing a coordinated, rapid and effective humanitarian response to those affected by crises in accordance with humanitarian standards and principles to reduce the excess mortality and over-morbidity of those affected. And in management and operations (OEEF - organisational effectiveness and efficiency Results Framework) there are four output clusters:. 1) Enhanced coordination, coherence and accountability of the UN system for gender equality commitment; 2) Increased engagement of partners in support of UN Women’s mandate; 3) Enhanced quality of programs through knowledge, innovation, RBM and evaluation; 4) Improved management of financial and human resources in pursuit of results. The separate project proposal for the response to the corona virus, sets the goal as: Effective management, prevention and response to the Covid-19 benefitting women, girls, boys and men, through adoption of strategic gender responsive approaches at community and local and national levels. Outcome 1. Incidence and impact of GBV is mitigated and minimised within local, national and COVID-response measures; Outcome 2. Social protection mechanisms and economic stimulus packages properly serve women and girls and are effectively targeted at their situations; Outcome 3: The broader public, and in particular men and boys, are supportive of and practise the equal sharing of unpaid care work arising from measures to manage the spread of COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Helvetas-Fast Avfall-WASH COVID-19 räddningsinsatser i Bolivia
COVID-19 Helvetas-Solid Waste-WASH COVID-19 emergency response in Bolivia

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Governments should consider the management of basic services such as water, sanitation and solid waste as essential public services within the framework of the response to COVID-19, in order to directly minimize impacts on health and the environment (rapid and uncontrolled spread of the virus in cities).
Management measures should consider all types of waste, including medical, domestic and hazardous waste, because there is a lot of pressure on the water supply service and large quantities of possibly infectious waste (chinstraps, masks, gloves, used or expired medicines and other contaminated items), which can easily be mixed with common waste, increasing the risk exposure of workers in the service providers. Therefore, it is necessary to consider the necessary biosafety measures to minimize such risk.
The disinfection procedures for contact and transit areas in places with a large influx of people, food supply areas, health service infrastructure, and military and police personnel facilities are other key activities that should be taken into account.
Finally, another problem that must be addressed is the issue of communication (access to information, training, and awareness) both for health service personnel, technical support teams that have been working on the response, and the population in general, through campaigns, technical assistance, and/or support in the dissemination of existing materials.
Within the framework of the health emergency, HELVETAS (as a humanitarian actor in the country) along with Agua Tuya and SwissContact (the three current partners with the Embassy in different contributions) have requested the financial assistance of the Embassy to support an emergency response in the WASH and solid waste sector.
The project is aimed at contributing to the prevention and containment of COVID-19 infection with emphasis on the management of environmental sanitation, cleaning and disinfection services in the municipalities of La Paz, El Alto and Montero. The expected amount of the whole contribution is 3 million SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Hanteringen av grundläggande behov som vatten, sanitet och fast avfall är en väsentlig offentlig service i bekämpningen av Covid-19. Sådan service kan minska virusets påverkan på hälsa och miljö (framförallt dess snabba och okontrollerade spridning i städer). Åtgärder för hanteringen av olika typer av avfall (mediciniskt, hushålls- och farligt avfall) är också betydelsefulla, då sådant avfall annars kan påverka vattenförsörjningen. Det finns också en risk för att smittsamt avfall blandas med vanligt avfall. Smittsamt avfall är exempelvis maskar, handskar, utgångna mediciner, och diverse produkter som kan bära smitta. Exponering för dessa typer av avfall utgör även en risk för den personal som upprätthåller avfallshantering och sanitetstjänster. Det är därför viktigt att genomföra nödvändiga åtgärder för biosäkerhet i avfallshanteringen i syfte att minska riskerna.
Åtgärder för desinfektion av kontakt- och transitplatser där folksamlingar kan bildas (exempelvis matbutiker, sjukhus, samt arbetsplatser för militär och polis) är ytterligare en viktig punkt som måste beaktas.
Slutligen måste svårigheter relaterade till behovet av fungerande kommunikation uppmärksammas (tillgång till information, utbildning och medvetenhet). Sådana åtgärder är av vikt för personal sysselsatt med hälsovård, smittspridning, samt befolkningen i stort. Behovet av kommunikation kan mötas med upplysningskampanjer, teknisk rådgivning, och/eller stöd till spridning av befintlig information.
I den aktuella situationen har Helvetas (som varande en humanitär aktör i Bolivia) i samarbete med AguaTuya och SwissContact ansökt om ekonomiskt stöd från Sida för att stödja krisåtgärder inom vatten-, sanitet- och avfallssektorerna. Alla tre aktörer är etablerade motparter för Sida.
Projektets syfte är att bidra till förebyggandet och begränsningen av Covid-19, med fokus på miljösanering, rengöring och desinfektion av offentliga miljöer i La Paz, El Alto och Montero. Det förväntade bidraget uppgår till tre miljoner svenska kronor.

The overall objective of the contribution is to minimize the risk of COVID-19 infection of personnel operating environmental sanitation services, and thus ensure their continuity in spite the health emergency.
This has been done through the support to the selected municipalities in: -The development of contingency plans and its implementation through the provision of personal safety garments and other inputs for the protection of workers of environmental sanitation services, - Providing training in cleaning and disinfection of people’s high concentration areas - Technical assistance for communication and public information processes.

tag.narrative: 11.5 - By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.

11.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet dödsfall och antalet människor som drabbas av katastrofer, inklusive vattenrelaterade katastrofer. Även tillse att de direkta ekonomiska förlusterna till följd av sådana katastrofer, i form av lägre global BNP, minskar väsentligt. Särskilt fokus bör ligga på att skydda de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Project was executed through the HELVETAS Swiss Intercooperation (HELVETAS) as the lead institution with Swisscontact and Aguatuya Foundation as the main third parties. Five activities have been planned during the whole implementation: Activity 1 Technical Assistance to Municipalities and WASH utilities in the design and implementation of contingency plans. Helvetas has developed “a service continuity tool in the context of COVID-19”. Its aim was to achieve continuity of vital services that are provided in municipalities and WASH utilities during the health emergency by limiting the exposure and protecting the personnel performing essential functions. The instrument has been validated in the water and sanitation utility of La Paz and El Alto (EPSAS) which is the biggest provider in Bolivia. It has been implemented in the municipalities of El Alto and the water and sanitation utilities of Montero and La Guardia. Helvetas along with their partners have also developed protocols for the provision of urban cleaning services. These protocols seek to improve the capacity of the municipalities to guarantee the continuity of operations in contexts of health emergencies where their employees are highly exposed to contagion due to the nature of their activities. It has been mainly implemented in the Municipality of La Guardia. Activity 2 Strengthen capacities through training courses to the technical staff, which was at risk of contagion due to their work in environmental sanitation: This specific activity has been carried out by Swisscontact through the National Institute of Health Laboratories (INLASA). The training activities have been developed in 38 health care establishments (including three WASH utilities and municipalities) making a total of 6,135 officials from the health sector and 224 officials from COSMOL and the company that provides waste collection and transportation services in the municipality of La Paz, La Paz Limpia. In order to standardize critical processes in health establishments, specific guidelines have been prepared in order to minimize the risk of this personnel. Activity 3 Provision of protection items (biosecurity inputs) to the technical staff within municipalities and WASH utilities. The project team has contacted the beneficiaries (WASH utilities and Municipalities) to confirm the main necessities for personal protection, defining the key items that were needed. It is important to mention that during the process of purchase, due to the high demand for many of these inputs, the prices of various items (disposable coveralls, chinstraps, among others) were more expensive and there was little availability of the required quantity. However, Helvetas has manged to deal with this situation. During the months of May and June, personal protection items were delivered to the autonomous municipal governments of La Paz and El Alto (for the workers in charge of the final disposal of solid waste generated in the landfills Saka Churu and Villa Ingenio) and EPSAS (for the workers that were working in the front line). In May and July, personal protection items were delivered to COSMOL (the WASH utility of Motero) and COSPLAG LR (the WASH Utility of La Guardia), contributing to the sustainability and continuity of the environmental sanitation services. In the month of July, EPSAS and the municipality of La Paz, given the increase of positive cases among their workers, requested additional support with personal protection elements to guarantee the continuity of work and prevent contagion. To meet this need, funds have been used from the contingency budget line. Activity 4- Provision of equipment and supplies for cleaning and disinfecting places with a high influx of people. In the months of May and June, supplies for cleaning and disinfection of public spaces with a high influx of people in the municipalities of La Paz and El Alto have been delivered. The main areas have been markets and public roads, reaching approximately 180 public spaces. In July, the Autonomous Municipal Government of El Alto, has requested additional support for the provision of “granular chlorine” to continue the cleaning and disinfection activities in public spaces due to the increase in cases in this city. To cover this need, funds have been used from the budget line for contingencies. In July, supplies for cleaning and disinfection of public spaces with a high influx of people were delivered in the municipalities of La Guardia achieving the disinfection of approximately 30 spaces. The logistics of this specific activity have been coordinated with the Vice Ministry of Civil Defense. Activity 5: Support the generation and dissemination of communication and information campaigns. A communication strategy has been implemented in the municipalities of El Alto, La Paz, La Guardia, Montero, producing differentiated messages to reach vulnerable groups, groups exposed to possible contagion (personnel who clean and disinfect public spaces, hospital waste operators and WASH Utilities) and the general population. The intended message has been oriented to promote a sense of co-responsibility in prevention, solid waste management and in the implementation of cleaning and disinfection measures. All communication actions have included an intercultural, gender and social equity approach. The contents have been disseminated through mass media and social networks (all the details of the messages and its dissemination are specified in the narrative report). Activity 6: Mega Tracking in La Paz This activity has not been planned in the original project document. However, and due to the high rate cases in the city of La Paz, the municipality has requested extra support to carry out this specific task. The Departmental Health Service of La Paz (SEDES) requested HELVETAS’ support for the transport of personnel to strengthen the operational action of the mega tracing in the city of La Paz. Having a small balance still to be executed and seeing the criticality of the epidemiological curve of contagion by COVID-19 in the department of La Paz, during the month of August, it was considered opportune to support SEDES in this operation of vital importance to contain the spread of the virus, especially in the municipalities of El Alto and La Paz. In this sense, and with a proper coordination within the Embassy, the request was carried out with the provision of transport and communication material on contagion prevention measures. This activity has been extremely important and has led the municipality and the National Government to take adequate measures regarding the de-confinement of cities and subsequent preventive measures based on an adequate strategy. Financial Report The budget execution of the Solid Waste-WASH COVID-19 emergency response in Bolivia Project for the period between April 27 and August 31, 2020 has been done according to the annex C specified in the agreement. As it has been mentioned above, some additional activities have been carried out under the contingency item budget line, in coordination with the Embassy. The accounting base of the project has been made under the modified cash base (mixed)” since most of the transactions were recorded under the cash method, except for the last payments pending at the end of the project which were carried out after the activity period ended (audit, etc.). The transactions incurred during the period of activities has been done applying the exchange rate of the single payment: 0.68069691 Bs / SEK (according to the bank). There has been a loss due to exchange differences of around Bs81,502.38 (SEK 107,602.93). This amount has been adjusted in the Contingency item budget line without affecting the expected results. Audit Report No major observations have been found in the audit report. Helvetas has complied with all the requirements.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19
COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Tbilisi for funding of one million and twenty thousand SEK to contribute to the "Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19" in Georgia during the period of three months, May-July 2020.
The intervention aims at contribute to preventing the spread of the Coronavirus and staying healthy by following: 1) Basic human needs of those affected by the new coronavirus outbreak have been met through provision of Red Cross services (food distribution, psychological first aid, psychosocial support, stress management, healthy lifestyle, incl. personal hygiene, etc.), as well as personal protective equipment to volunteer workers and Red Cross staff; 2) Raised awareness of the general public, local communities, mass media, and civil society sector through information campaigns as well as online training carried out by well mobilized and trained Red Cross and community volunteers.
The GRCS's open emergency plan with total budget is around 7.5 million SEK, for which the GRCS has made an open call and till now managed to mobilize already more than 6 million SEK. Among other donors, the Embassy of Swiss Confederation in Georgia and USAID Georgia have already contributed to the GRCS response plan.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Georgiska Röda Korset (GRCS) har ansökt om stöd från svenska ambassaden i Tbilisi om en budget på 1 020 000 MSEK för att bidra till organisationens kris- och beredskapsrespons för COVID-19 , under perioden maj - juli 2020.
Insatsen syfte är att bidra till att förebygga spridning av coronaviruset samt att upprätthålla en god folkhälsa genom följande målsättningar: 1) Möta grundläggande mänskliga behov bland den del av befolkningen drabbats hårt av det nya Coronaviruset, genom Röda Korsets tjänster (matdistribution, första hjälpen till psykologiskt drabbade, psykosocialt stöd, stresshantering, hälsosam livsstil inklusive personlig hygien, osv.), även skyddsutrustning till volontärer och Röda Korsets personal; 2) Öka medvetenheten inom samhället genom informationskampanjer och webbaserade utbildningar genomförda av mobiliserade och utbildade Röda Korset- och samhällsvolontärer.
GRCS:s kris- och beredskapsrespons för COVID-19 har en total budget på 7,5 MSEK, varav drygt 6 MSEK hittills har mobiliserats genom öppet. Bland andra bidragsgivarna återfinns bland andra USAID och den schweiziska ambassaden i Georgien.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
3.d - Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.

description.narrative: The following key results were achieved by he partner, Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS): - GRCS has provided the humanitarian aid and distributed in total 1,230 food and hygiene parcels to lonely, older people and persons with special needs in different regions of Georgia, as well as provided parcels to the National Tuberculosis Center. - Through, GRCS Emergency Appeal, up to 5,000 volunteers and 4,500 public servants and NGO employees were trained on COVID-19 and safety measures. - The GRCS volunteers carried out activities, such as information campaigns, supporting health workers in COVID-19 testing, provision of psychological first aid through the GRCS hotline service to minimise risks that the people, especially, lonely, older people and persons with special needs were facing. Through the hotline service, the GRCS has also managed to help up to 8,000 citizens of Georgia. - Out of above-mentioned volunteers,over 100 volunteers were involved in the implementation of this project. These volunteers, who were trained and equipped with personal protective items,were delivering services to the affected people in shifts and disseminating the risk communication messages along with the WHO recommendations to local communities in target locations. - The GRCS has developed, published and disseminated COVID-related information educational materials like posters, leaflets,brochures, as well as prepared the videoson COVID-19 and the recommendations to prevent and control the spread of COVID-19, thus encouraging the people to stay at home and safe. These materials have been published in Georgian, Azerbaijani,Armenian, Ossetian, and Abkhazian languages, and disseminated among the entire population, national minorities among them. - The anti-COVID-19 operations and services have been well coordinated with the central government and the municipalities’ authorities, as well as with non-state actors. Challenge for the GRCS during the implementation, has been the transition to doing more and more activities online, including the coordination of these activities, which GRCS successfully managed. As part of the monitoring measures, the Embassy representatives have also made field visit to observe the distribution of the parcels at the National Center for the Tuberculosis first hand and also spoke to the Center's representative about the significance of such support.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
