description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Purpose The purpose of the contribution is to support the implementation of the continental Covid-19 strategy "Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak". The strategy was adopted by the African Union (all Africa's 55 health ministers/health ministries) on February 22, 2020 during a crisis meeting. The strategy has two overarching goals: to prevent severe disease and death from Covid-19 infection in member states and to minimize the social and economic consequences of the Covid-19 outbreak.
An Addendum to the strategy has also been developed, the AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, which includes specific reference to ensure access to basic health care, including maternal and child health care during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Henceforth, it should be noted that the reference to strategy includes both the Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak” and its Addendum. The strategy includes the following pillars: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; and Science, Standards and Regulations.
Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a specialized agency of the African Union. Africa CDC has been tasked by the African Union to implement the strategy.
Sida intends to support the Africa CDC with 20 million SEK to implement the pillars focused on Coordination and Collaboration and Risk Communication and Social Engagement.
This has been determined in consultation with the EU and other member states that constitute Team Europe, which includes Sweden. The arrangement means that the EU and the member states (Spain, Sweden, Germany and Austria) are coordinated through a joint budget and work plan and joint reporting (both narrative and financial, including audit). Team Europe's total support amounts to EUR 25.85 million (includes SEK 20 million from Sida). Attached document “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” sets out all relevant details. However, it should be noted that Sweden will enter into a bilateral/separate agreement with Africa CDC.
Sida will contribute to Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak and its Addendum through two other contributions: WHO-AFRO (SEK 30 million) and Together4SRHR (SEK 30 million through an amendment to the agreement). Sida views the contributions as three parts of a coherent support in line with the above strategy, and comprises a total of SEK 80 million.
The strategy is implemented through the Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), where Africa CDC, UN and AU member countries lead working groups, and through Africa CDC's Incident Management System (IMS). A number of partners, both UN and non-state actors, also contribute to the implementation of the strategy.
These implementing partners are financed either directly by aid donors who finance supplementary efforts, or via Africa CDC, which then transfers funds to implementing partners.
Context The reason that the contribution (without an explicit focus on SRHR) is funded by the regional SRHR strategy is because of the expected consequences of COVID-19. These are anticipated to be dramatic and all-encompassing regarding the development spectrum – encompassing e.g., social and economic aspects.
Africa CDC reports that with regards to its member states that there on 25 June 2020 was: 337,315 cases; and 8,863 deaths. Clearly, it is important to note that these are only reported/confirmed cases and that numbers rapidly increase daily.
Despite the various measures in place, the virus is likely to spread further and likely to continue to have significant impacts on e.g., the economy and livelihoods of the populations of the African continent. The social, health and development impacts of the pandemic on the continent are currently devastating and could signify a reversal of the development gains of the previous decades - there are already evidence that point to this direction.
The World Bank estimates that Sub-Saharan African economies could lose between USD 37 to USD 79 billion in 2020 due to consequences of COVID-19. Economic growth could contract from 2.4% in 2019 to -5.1% in 2020, bringing about the first recession in 25 years.
Sida notes that a challenge attached to the contribution could be longer term institutional strengthening and sustainability given that the focus and purpose is intertwined with COVID-19 and its trajectory. The agreement will cover a one year implementation period and entail a one-off disbursement. Nonetheless, there are reasons to assume that there will rippling effects and that the contribution will help also to strengthen Africa’s national public health institutions’ capacities to reduce the overall disease burden on the continent – beyond the COVID-19 pandemic. The issue of sustainability will be an ongoing dialogue issue between Sweden, Africa CDC, the EU and other relevant stakeholders.
Sida recognizes that the work of Africa CDC is crucial as health is a development issue that affects the economic, social and security concerns of countries and regions. This is especially apparent when infections or epidemics occur as became apparent during the Ebola outbreak in West Africa in 2014/2015 and again during the current COVID-19 pandemic.
Sida also takes note of the precarious situation on the African continent, which currently faces the burden of communicable and non-communicable diseases (NCDs), and injury and trauma. This is combined with fragile health systems and inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene infrastructure, population mobility that will make key preventing measures such as physical distancing very difficult to uphold, and contribute to increase susceptibility for unrest.
Challenges resulting from several infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, TB and malaria), maternal mortality as well as outbreaks such as yellow fever, cholera and natural disasters (as a result of climate change and conflict), still affect the continent adversely and continue to pose serious threats alongside the current COVID-19 pandemic, which will likely cause widespread illness and death in Africa (according to Africa CDC). One factor that could mitigate deaths in Africa is demography; more than 50 percent of the population is under 20 years old, a group that has been relatively spared from illness and death from COVID-19 across the world.
Overall with regards to health security, the Ebola crisis in 2014-2015 highlighted the unpreparedness of health systems in Africa. It was then made clear that health systems in Africa are unable to adequately cope with major health crises. Urgent and collective action is now needed to protect the African region from the health security threat that the COVID-19 pandemic poses.
It is clear that capacity gaps are due to insufficient resources (financial, human, and logistics) and fragmented services. Furthermore, limited community engagement, weak health systems, inadequate inter-country collaborations, and limited effective partnerships.
Across the world, African countries are least prepared for epidemics or pandemics. All African countries lack foundational health systems capacities for vital epidemic and pandemic response and national health security is fundamentally weak across the African continent. There are also severe weaknesses in countries’ abilities to prevent, detect, and respond to health emergencies; vulnerabilities to political, socioeconomic, and environmental risks that can confound outbreak preparedness and response; and, a lack of adherence to international norms.
Africa CDC acts now to support African countries to address these gaps through coordination and to strengthen preparedness and response through partnerships.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Syfte Insatsens syfte är att stödja implementeringen av den kontinentala covid-19 strategin ”Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”. Strategin antogs av den Afrikanska Unionen (alla Afrikas 55 hälsoministrar/hälsoministerier) 22 februari 2020 under ett krismöte. Strategin har två övergripande mål: att förebygga svår sjukdom och död av Covid-19 infektion i medlemsländer och att minimera sociala och ekonomiska konsekvenser av covid-19 utbrottet.
Ett tillägg finns även till strategin, AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, som inkluderar specifik referens till att säkerställa tillgång till grundläggande hälsosjukvård, inklusive mödrabarnhälsovård under covid-19 pandemin.
Med strategin menas hädanefter både Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum.
Strategin omfattar följande pelare: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; och Science, Standards and Regulations.
Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) är en institution som tillhör den Afrikanska Unionen. Africa CDC har av den Afrikanska Unionen fått uppdraget att implementera strategin.
Sida avser att stödja Africa CDC med 20 miljoner SEK för implementerandet av pelare fokuserade på Coordination and Collaboration och Risk Communication and Social Engagement.
Detta har bestämts i samråd med EU och andra medlemsstater som utgör Team Europe där Sverige ingår. Upplägget innebär at EU och medlemsstaterna (Spanien, Sverige, Tyskland och Österrike) är samordnade under en gemensam budget och arbetsplan och gemensam rapportering (både narrativ och finansiell, inklusive revision). Team Europes totala stöd utgör EUR 25,85 miljoner (inkluderar 20 miljoner SEK från Sida). Bilagt dokument “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” redogör för alla relevanta detaljer. Det bör dock noteras att Sverige kommer att ingå ett bilateralt/separat avtal med Kommissionen för den Afrikanska Unionen.
Sida kommer att bidra till Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum genom två andra insatser WHO-AFRO (30 miljoner SEK) och Together4SRHR (30 miljoner SEK genom en avtalsändring). Sida ser på insatserna som tre delar av ett sammanhållet stöd i linje med ovan nämnda strategi, och omfattar totalt 80 miljoner SEK.
Den kontinentala COVID-19 strategin implementeras genom Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), där Africa CDC, FN och AU:s medlemsländer leder arbetsgrupper, och genom Africa CDC’s Incident Management System (IMS). Ett antal partners, både FN och ickestatliga aktörer, bidrar också till att implementera strategin.
Dessa implementerande partners finansieras antingen direkt av biståndsgivare som finansierar kompletterande insatser, eller via Africa CDC som sedan vidareförmedlar medel till implementerande partners.
Kontext Anledningen till att insatsen (utan ett uttryckligt fokus på SRHR) finansieras av den regionala SRHR-strategin är på grund av de förväntade konsekvenserna av COVID-19. Dessa förväntas vara dramatiska och allomfattande vad gäller utvecklingsspektrumet - som t.ex. omfattar sociala och ekonomiska aspekter, och COIVD-19 riskerar att tränga undan annan grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård, inklusive tjänster för sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa.
Africa CDC rapporterar att det bland sina medlemsländer, den 25 juni 2020 ,fanns: 337 315 bekräftade fall av Covid-19; och 8 863 bekräftade dödsfall till följd av Covid-19. Det bör noteras att dessa endast avser rapporterade/bekräftad fall och att antalet snabbt ökar dagligen.
Trots att olika åtgärder har vidtagits kommer viruset enligt olika beräkningar att spridas ytterligare och fortsätta att ha betydande effekter på t.ex. ekonomin och livsmedelsförsörjningen på den afrikanska kontinenten. De sociala, hälso- och utvecklingseffekterna av pandemin på kontinenten är för närvarande förödande och kan innebära att utvecklingsvinningar under de senaste decennierna urholkas. Det finns redan bevis som pekar på denna riktning.
Världsbanken uppskattar att de afrikanska ekonomierna söder om Sahara kan förlora mellan 37 och 79 miljarder USD under år 2020 till följd av Covid-19 konsekvenser. Den ekonomiska tillväxten kan minska från 2,4% 2019 till -5,1% 2020, vilket skulle leda till den första lågkonjunkturen på 25 år.
Sida konstaterar att en utmaning kopplad till insatsen kan vara långsiktigt institutionellt stärkande och hållbarhet med tanke på att fokus och syfte är sammanflätade med Covid-19 och dess utveckling.
Avtalet täcker en implementeringsperiod på ett år och innebär en engångsutbetalning. Det finns emellertid skäl att anta att insatsen kommer att ha bredare effekter och att insatsen också kommer att bidra till att stärka Afrikas nationella folkhälsoinstitutioners kapacitet för att minska den totala sjukdomsbördan på kontinenten bortom Covid-19-pandemin. Hållbarhet kommer att vara en pågående dialogfråga mellan Sverige, Africa CDC, EU och andra relevanta aktörer.
Sida anser att Africa CDC:s arbete är mycket viktigt eftersom hälsa är en utvecklingsfråga som påverkar de ekonomiska, sociala och säkerhetsmässiga aspekterna i länder och regioner. Detta är särskilt uppenbart när det gäller infektioner eller epidemier. Detta visade sig under Ebola-utbrottet i Västafrika 2014/2015 och återigen under den nuvarande COVID-19-pandemi.
Sida noterar också den osäkra situationen på den afrikanska kontinenten, som för närvarande står inför bördan av smittsamma och icke-smittsamma sjukdomar, skador och trauma. Detta kombineras med bräckliga hälsosystem och otillräcklig infrastruktur för vatten, sanitet och hygien och stor befolkningsrörlighet. Detta kommer att göra viktiga förebyggande åtgärder som fysisk distansering mycket svåra att upprätthålla och öka risken för oroligheter.
Utmaningar till följd av flera infektionssjukdomar (t.ex. HIV, TB och malaria), mödradödlighet samt utbrott som gulafeber, kolera och naturkatastrofer (som ett resultat av klimatförändringar och konflikter), påverkar fortfarande kontinenten negativt och fortsätter att utgöra allvarliga hot tillsammans med den nuvarande Covid-19 pandemin, som sannolikt kommer att orsaka utbredd sjukdom och död i Afrika (enligt Africa CDC). En faktor som kan mildra dödsfall i Afrika är demografi; mer än 50 procent av befolkningen är under 20 år gammal, en grupp som över hela världen har relativt förskonats från sjukdom och död till följd av Covid-19.
Övergripande när det gäller hälsosäkerhet visade Ebolakrisen 2014–2015 att hälsosystem i Afrika inte kan hantera stora hälsokriser på ett tillfredsställande sätt. Brådskande och kollektiva åtgärder behövs nu för att skydda den afrikanska regionen från det hälsohot som Covid-19-pandemin utgör.
Det är uppenbart att kapacitetsbrister beror på otillräckliga resurser (ekonomiska, mänskliga och logistiska) och fragmenterade tjänster. Dessutom finns andra stora utmaningar, t.ex. begränsat samhällsengagemang, svaga hälsosystem, otillräckliga samarbeten mellan länder och begränsade effektiva partnerskap.
Över hela världen är afrikanska länder minst förberedda på att hantera epidemier eller pandemier. I alla afrikanska länder saknas grundläggande kapacitet bland hälsosystem för att effektivt bekämpa epidemier och pandemier. Det finns även allvarliga brister i ländernas förmåga att förebygga, upptäcka och bemöta hälsohot; hög utsatthet för politiska, socioekonomiska och miljömässiga risker som kan försvåra beredskap och hanterandet av utbrott; och bristande efterlevnad av internationella normer.
Africa CDC agerar nu för att stödja afrikanska länder att hantera dessa brister genom att samordna, och stärka beredskap och respons genom partnerskap.

The first and foremost purpose of the intended contribution is to enable Africa CDC to promptly and systematically implement “The Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”, endorsed by the AU. The articulated goals of the strategy are to: prevent severe morbidity and mortality from COVID-19 infection in African Union (AU) member states; and, to minimize social disruption and economic consequences of COVID-19 outbreaks. The strategy has two objectives: coordinate efforts of AU member states, AU agencies, WHO, and other partners and stakeholder to ensure synergy and minimize duplication; and, promote evidence-based public health practice for surveillance, prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and control of COVID-19. Consequently, beyond the pressing need to ensure 1) effective coordination and collaboration, the strategy (and the addendum - i.e., implementation plan) stipulates that efforts will be dedicated to: 2) Surveillance: Collect, analyze, and disseminate accurate, timely data about the epidemiology of COVID-19. 3) Laboratory: Ensure quality-assured testing for COVID-19 diagnosis, genotyping, and special studies. 4) Countermeasures: Support implementation of evidence-based interventions at individual and population-level to reduce COVID-19 transmission. 5) Healthcare preparedness: Strengthen capacity of healthcare facilities to manage surge in patient visits and to effectively identify, isolate, and manage people with COVID-19 infection. 6) Risk communication and social engagement: Provide guidance that is clear, comprehensible, evidence based, culturally appropriate, and adapted to special populations and circumstances. 7) Supply chain management: Establish and maintain supply chains for shared resources, including personal protective equipment, laboratory supplies and equipment, and, if available and necessary, medical countermeasures. 8) Special populations, settings, and policies: Assess and manage issues related to special populations (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons), analyze and guide on ethical and legal issues (e.g., quarantine, healthcare triage, travel, trade), and develop plans for continuity of essential public health operations (e.g., maternal child health programs, immunizations). 9) Science, standards and regulations: Ensure that timelyand coordinated scientific and policy information is made available to decision makers within AU member states. The Sida funds will be dedicated to pillar 1) effective coordination and collaboration and pillar 6) risk communication and social engagement. In terms of specific results, the Swedish contribution will primarily contribute to: -A more effectively functioning Africa CDC, including improved functions in regional coordination, epi analysis, and partnership development. -Reductions in disease spread in countries where community health workers were deployed due to more effective public health behaviors (e.g., physical distancing, mask wearing, hand washing etc.). This has been agreed with the EU and other member states, who will fund other pillars and results - all in a harmonized approach. Through the Team Europe, also the following results will be achieved (to be funded by other members): - Improvements in healthcare outcomes (e.g., lower spread of cases and less severe cases) in IDP and refugee camp settings. - Improved member state capacity in surveillance and detection through technical experts, trainings, and community health workers. - Increase in testing rates in countries where lab supplies are distributed. - Improvements in testing, tracing and treatment outcomes in countries where community health workers and rapid responders are deployed. The joint Team Europe work plan and budget outlines what the EU as an entity and each EU member state will fund, and should thus be consulted for details. It should be noted that the Swedish contribution has also been harmonized with the support to WHO-AFRO and the Together4SRHR platform and is in line with the relevant Swedish strategy for the regional SRHR team (see the appraisal plan regarding details pertaining to the 2 relevant Swedish government strategies).

description.narrative: The goal of the proposed programme is to mitigate the consequences of Covid-19 on the health system with provision of essential health commodities to ensure the continuation of essential health services delivery in 4 provinces of Zambia. The programme is intended to promote resilience of the health system as a mitigation for Covid-19 impact by ensuring essential health commodity security especially focused on vaccines, essential medicines and supplies for reproductive, maternal, newborn, child and adolescent health services. The aim is to serve an estimated 1 million people with primary health care services, 375 000 infants with routine vaccination services and 380 000 pregnant women with maternal health supplies. The programme will also procure and distribute personal protective equipment, oxygen concentrators and infection prevention supplies for 5 000 health workers to avoid Covid-19 infection and ensure a healthy and safe work environment. The supplies are estimated to serve patients for a period of 6 months but the programme duration will be 1,5 years to ensure consistent monitoring, oversight and follow-up as well as capacity-building. More specifically, the key results will be: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 3 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 2 months. UPDATE The key results have been updated to reflect the additional 15 Million SEK from Sida. These are some of the key results with sligthly revised figures: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). No change. - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 6 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 4 months. - An estimated 4000 newborns receiving quality essential newborn care services at 5 hospitals in the 4 provinces and at UTH Lusaka. NEW - 22 health facilities equipped with cold chain equipment. NEW - Provincial Vaccines Store in Muchinga restored. NEW - 4 hospitals equipped with recommissioned oxygen plants to treat critical patients including covid-19. NEW - 5 hospitals equipped with neonatal supplies for quality essential newborn care services and 30 health workers trained. NEW

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNICEF has applied to Sida for support to Multisectoral response to Covid 19: Building Resilient and Integrated Essential Services for Underserved Communities in Cox’s Bazar and Gazipur Districts, Bangladesh.
In partnership with the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) International and National Non-Governmental Organizations and Civil Society Organizations UNICEF proposes to contribute to the reduction of the adverse impacts of COVID-19 on poor and vulnerable children and women in two districts of Bangladesh. This project complements GoB’s commitment to achieve food security and improved nutrition, ensuring healthy lives and promoting wellbeing at all ages and elimination of different forms of violence to women and adolescent girls, by improving their human capabilities.
The Integrated Package of Services proposed are aligned with the Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan (BPRP) for COVID-19 health response and address the critical lifesaving interventions in nutrition, WASH, and protection including GBV and are essential to minimize the impact of the pandemic among vulnerable children and women. The proposal is developed in consultation with Government of Bangladesh and multisectoral partners.
The proposed one-year project will contribute to the following outcomes by addressing at the national level key issues of targeting and quality of social protection and in the districts of Gazipur and Cox's Bazar focused on strengthening systems and access to social protection and social services for women and children in poor and vulnerable communities by:
I. Enhanced capacity of essential services and personnel to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks and provide quality health, nutrition, child protection, GBV, water, hygiene, waste management and sanitation services
II. Advocate to expand the coverage and strengthen effectiveness of national social protection system and ensure the urgent release, reunification, and reintegration of children in juvenile detention facilities and other institutions.
III. Integrated support to the Bangladeshi host communities and Rohingya refugees undergoing treatment for COVID-19 at the 200 bed SARI ITC in Teknaf, Cox's Bazar District.
The intervention budget is 30 000 000 SEK and will be financed by Sida.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNICEF har ansökt till Sida om stöd till Sektorövergripande COVID-19 respons: Uppbyggnad av resilient och integrerad grundläggande service för utsatta grupper i Cox's Bazar och Gazipur i Bangladesh.
I samarbete med Bangladesh regering samt internationella och nationella civilsamhällsorganisationer vill UNICEF bidra till att minska de negativa effekterna av COVID-19 för fattiga och utsatta barn och kvinnor i två distrikt i Bangladesh. Detta projekt kompletterar Bangladesh regerings åtagande att nå livsmedelssäkerhet och förbättrad nutrition, säkerställa och främja god hälsa i alla åldrar och eliminera olika former av våld mot kvinnor och tonårsflickor genom att stärka kapacitet.
Den föreslagna insatsen är anpassad till Bangladeshs beredskaps- och responsplan (BPRP) för hälsorespons på COVID-19 och omfattar insatser inom nutrition, vatten och sanitet och skydd inklusive könsbaserat våld för att minimera effekterna av pandemin bland utsatta barn och kvinnor. Insatsen har utvecklats i samråd med Bangladeshs regering och partners inom flera sektorer.
Det föreslagna ettåriga projektet kommer att bidra till följande resultat genom att på nationell nivå ta itu med frågor kring inriktning och kvalitet på socialt skydd samt i distrikten Gazipur och Cox's Bazar med fokus på att stärka system och tillgång till socialt skydd och social service för kvinnor och barn i fattiga och utsatta områden genom:
I. Förbättrad kapacitet på service och personal för att respondera på COVID-19-utbrottet och tillhandahålla service inom hälsa, nutrition, barnskydd, könsbaserat våld, vatten, hygien, avfallshantering och sanitet.
II. Arbeta för att utvidga täckningen och stärka effektiviteten i det nationella sociala skyddssystemet och säkerställa ett snabbt frisläppande, återförening och återintegrering av barn vid ungdomsfängelser och andra institutioner.
III. Integrerat stöd till värdsamhällen och Rohingya-flyktingar som genomgår behandling för COVID-19 vid 200-bädds SARI ITC i Teknaf, Cox's Bazar-distrikt.
Insatsbudgeten är 30 000 000 SEK och kommer att finansieras av Sida.

The proposed one-year project will contribute to the following outcomes by addressing at the national level key issues of targeting and quality of social protection and in the two districts through an integrated package focused on strengthening systems and access to social protection and social services for women and children in poor and vulnerable communities by end of July 2021 through the following actions: I. Enhanced capacity of essential services and personnel to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks and provide quality health, nutrition, child protection, GBV, water, hygiene, waste management and sanitation services to underserved women, children and vulnerable communities in Gazipur District and City Corporation.II. Advocate to expand the coverage and strengthen effectiveness of national social protection system and ensure the urgent release, reunification, and reintegration of children in juvenile detention facilities and other institutions. III. Integrated support to the Bangladeshi host communities and Rohingya refugees undergoing treatment for COVID-19 at the 200 bed SARI ITC in Teknaf, CxB District. The proposed interventions will be implemented under the leadership of GoB within the existing structures including those at institutional and community levels. Systems strengthening, preparedness, and addressing key underlying issues will support governments efforts to improve effectiveness of national social security system and to suppress COVID-19 in the two districts. In CxB for instance, it is projected that at least 1,000 beds will be needed for an isolation and treatment centre for the expected COVID-19 cases both for Rohingya refugees and the host communities. In Gazipur, systems issues will be addressed to ensure adequate access to integrated social services. Evidence will be developed for policy engagement and policy influencing on social protection, public health and basic service delivery both in urban and rural Bangladesh. The interventions will also reduce protection risks for children and women including physical violence, trafficking, early marriages and child labour which are prevalent in the two districts. Lastly, the proposed budget of USD 3,108,949.80 will support the stipulated interventions, strengthening systems and communities, addressing underlying fragilities towards a more resilient approach to lower transmission of COVID-19 and to better respond to future public health challenges in Bangladesh.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution-Multisectoral response to COVID -19 UNICEF
COVID-19 Multi-sectoral Program on Food Security COVID-19
COVID-19 Multi-sectoral Program on Food Security COVID-19

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 World Food Programme (WFP) in Bangladesh has, together with Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) applied to Sida for funding of 30 million SEK to carry out the "Cross-sectoral response to the COVID-19 instigated food and nutrition security crisis in Bangladesh" during the period 2020-2021, starting in November 2020.
The project is a part of the larger country strategic programme of World Food Programme, Bangladesh and aims to responds to critical food security needs for ultra-poor following the COVID-19 outbreak and the following socio-economic effects. The project specifically aims to increase access to, and availability of, fresh food commodities at affordable buying prices for urban poor, and to strengthen the supply chain of the commodities so that the rural farmers can produce and sell those commodities at reasonable prices.
The project will target a total population of 17,500 (3500 households from urban areas and 2500 farmers from rural areas) people living in low-income, at-risk, urban (Dhaka north) and rural areas (neighborhoods in Dhaka). The interventions in urban areas will focus on at-risk, low-income urban areas, where there will be an effort to (1) (re) establish a regular supply of fresh food to the inhabitants of the identified and targeted areas, and (2) provide direct cash assistance to poor and vulnerable living in these areas (and who meet specific selection criteria) . The interventions in rural areas will focus on the protection of the food and nutrition security and livelihoods of vulnerable rural households through (re) establishing linkages with market and food supply-chains to the targeted areas in urban centers. These activities will increase income and employment opportunities, create access to poor and vulnerable people to work as a producer, worker and/or consumer in the entire supply chain.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 World Food Program (WFP) i Bangladesh har, tillsammans med Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), ansökt om finansiering från Sida om 30 miljoner kronor för att genomföra projektet "Cross-sectoral response to the COVID-19 instigated food and nutrition security crisis in Bangladesh" under perioden 2020-2021, med start i november 2020.
Projektet är en del av av det strategiska landprogram som World Food Programme genomför i Bangladesh och syftar till att svara på kritiska livsmedelssäkerhetsbehov för extremt fattiga efter COVID-19-utbrottet samt påföljande socioekonomiska effekter. Projektet syftar specifikt till att öka tillgången till och tillgången på färska livsmedelsvaror till överkomliga priser för fattiga i städerna och att stärka distributionskedjan för råvaror så att landsbygdens jordbrukare kan producera och sälja sina varor till rimliga priser.
Projektet kommer att rikta sig till en total befolkning på 17 500 (3 500 hushåll från stadsområden och 2 500 jordbrukare från landsbygdsområden) låginkomsttagare i urbana områden (Dhaka norr) och landsbygdsområden (stadsdelar i större Dhaka). Insatserna i stadsområden kommer att fokusera på särskilt utsatta stadsområden, där projektet kommer att syfta till att (1) (åter-) etablera en regelbunden leverans av färsk mat till invånarna i de identifierade och riktade områdena, och ( 2) ge direkt kontanthjälp till fattiga och utsatta boende i dessa områden, som uppfyller specifika urvalskriterier. Insatserna på landsbygden kommer att fokusera på skydd av livsmedels- och näringsförsörjning och försörjning hos utsatta landsbygdshushåll genom att (åter-) upprätta kopplingar till livsmedels- och distributionskedjor till riktade utsatta områden. Dessa aktiviteter avses öka inkomsterna och sysselsättningsmöjligheterna, skapa tillgång till fattiga och utsatta människor att arbeta som matproducent, arbetare och/eller konsument i försörjningskedjan.

The overall aim of the project is to target (urban) households and (rural) farmers most impacted by COVID-19 and restore broken supply chains. The expected outcome is: Enhanced food and nutrition security and improved diets of nutritionally vulnerable household members, including pregnant and lactating women and young children. The contribution will address the food security needs of 20,000 beneficiaries; i.e. 17,500 individuals (3500 households) in at-risk low-income urban areas of Dhaka and smaller urban municipalities near Dhaka, with a focus on establishing linkages with 2,500 local smallholder farmers in semi-rural and rural areas of Dhaka North City Corporation (linking to smallholder farmers and producer organizations in Cumilla district, Chittagong). The programme is designed over a ten-month period, in order to sustain the short-term impact of the programme on household-level food security, and to create a model that the government can replicate and scale up. Recognising that the COVID-19 crisis is ongoing, and at risk of escalating, and that the full repercussions of the national lockdown is not yet known, the project has a built-in flexibility to adjust to a changing situation. The programme has following objective and outcomes: Objective: Enhance Food security for households most affected by the COVID-19 crisis in at-risk low-income urban areas Outcome 1: Most affected HHs by the COVID-19 crisis have enhanced food security Outcome 2: Re-established and regular supply of fresh food to the inhabitants of the identified and targeted areas

tag.narrative: 1.3 - Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
1.3 - Införa nationellt lämpliga system och åtgärder för socialt skydd för alla, inklusive grundskydd, och senast 2030 säkerställa att de omfattar en väsentlig andel av de fattiga och de utsatta.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 UNICEF component of 15 000 000 SEK Water, Sanitation and Hygiene sector response to COVID-19 in Kenya 2019/2020, in the HUM/ development nexus; Water supply to prevent and control infection, Sanitation & Hygiene, community sensitation for new social norms for hygiene behaviour, and support to improved coordination of external support to Kenya in WASH during the COVID-19 crisis.
Part of the programme will be implemented by UNICEF themselves, others will be implemented by third parties. either through procurement, or through forwarding of funds. The programme is an add-on to already existing UNICEF initiatives in the sector, with existing routines, and the implementation risk is generally seen as low. For the Sanitation & Hygiene Component, the local organisation Sanergy has already been identified through application procedure.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 15 000 000 SEK bidrag till UNICEFs intervention, via Vatten, Sanitet och Hygien-sektorn, till åtgärder mot COVID-19 i Kenya 2019/2020, i gränssnittet mellan humanitärt och och långsiktigt utvecklingsarbete; Vattenförsörjning för att förebygga och kontrollera smitta, sanitet och hygien, informationsarbete för nya hygien-normer, samt förbättrad samordning av externt stöd till Kenya inom vatten, sanitet och hygien under COVID-19-krisen. En del av insatsen kommer att genomföras av UNICEF själva, andra genomföras av tredje part, dels genom upphandling, dels genom vidareförmedling. Insatsen är en påbyggnad på redan pågående UNICEF-program, med inarbetade rutiner, och risken i genomförandet anses genomgående låg. För sanitets- och hygien komponenten har den lokala organisationen Sanergy redan identifierats genom ansökningsförfarande.

The overall objective of the intervention is to Contribute to infection prevention and control of COVID-19 through a set of integrated interventions covering water supply, sanitation and hygiene services in communities and health care facilities, combined with the promotion of behaviour change. In addition, the project will enhance coordination and monitoring of the WASH sector response through provision of an on-line monitoring platform that will increase accountability and transparency. Components: 1. Water supply - Enabling Infection Prevention and Control; Last mile connections of water pipes with pre-paid water meters and subsidised smart token for the needy in Nairobi and Nakuru slums. 2. Sanitation & Hygiene - Innovation to address both immediate and long term needs; Sanitation and handwashing facilities in Mukuru and Mathare slums in Nairobi. 3. Community sensitisation - Creating new social norms for hygiene behaviour; To counteract misinformation about COVID 19, engagement of populations in participatory analysis and communication. 4. Coordination & Monitoring [of sector response] - Enhanced through an on-line monitoring platform; Support the WASH COVID-19 Cluster monitoring (UNICEF co-chairing with Ministry of Health and Ministry of Water, Sanitation and Irrigation).

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Generation Unlimited in WB (incl. COVID-19)
COVID-19 Generation Unlimited på VB (inkl. COVID-19)

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The COVID-19 pandemic is having a major disruptive effect on the lives of young people in the Western Balkans. The overall consequences of the pandemic have left many young people feeling isolated, stressed and uncertain about their education, employment, or a stable income and their futures. The closures of schools are disproportionately impacting disadvantaged youth who have fewer educational opportunities outside of school. Young people are also particularly hard hit by job losses as they tend to hold more precarious jobs, have less work experience and hold contracting arrangements that are less protective of their rights than older workers. All of this has detrimental consequences to their mental health and wellbeing, as young people try to adapt and thrive in a very uncertain future, increasingly seeing migration as a solution.
In this contribution “Generation Unlimited in Western Balkans”, 2020-2021, UNICEF intends to respond to the needs of young people in Western Balkans related to the uncertainties of Covid-19. The Generation Unlimited (GenU) secretariat has selected Kosovo as the front runner in the upcoming project in Western Balkans. GenU is a global multi-sector partnership to meet the urgent need for expanded education, training and employment opportunities for young people, aged 10 to 24, on an unprecedented scale. As a front runner for GENU, UNICEF office in Kosovo plays a leading and catalyst role for UNICEF offices in Western Balkans in exploring scalable solutions for youth empowerment and employment. GenU will bring together UNICEF, private sector aims to provide at least 500 young people with internships in the private sector, government, civil society organizations and young people to address the urgent need to invest on bridging secondary- age education and training, employment and entrepreneurship opportunities to young people.
During 2020 Sida intends to support the contribution as one part in the establishing of GenU on Western Balkans and give response to the particular vulnerability of youths due to the economic consequences of COVID-19.
The expected results of the contribution to “Generation Unlimited in Western Balkans” is to:
a) at least 500 young people are trained and certified and provided with the opportunity to conduct paid internship in private sector, government, NGO’s, UN Agencies and other organizations. b) the match-making and virtual learning platform for internship will be developed and provide with online-learning opportunities for young people. Learning component will combine best educational and business practices for the 21st century skills needed for young people. c) at least 50 businesses, NGO and central and local level institutions will be mobilized to host internship placement of young people; d) a regional GenU initiative action plan will be developed.
The following project activities will be performed:
1) Identify and empower private sector enterprises and other institutions to host young people The GenU platform will facilitate the process and bring together private sector enterprises, civil society organizations, local and central level institutions and other international organizations to host interns. However, as the most important hosting with capacities and interest to improve their performance and respond to the issue of COVID-19 are private sector businesses. Through the CSR network, only during the launch of the project 22 businesses (members of CSR) and their leaders are on board. In addition, CSR Network will play the convening role to enhance partnership by bringing more private enterprises on board to reach its total of 100 members in a 1-year period. 2) Develop and deploy a matching platform that will enable 3 months paid internship for young people: the proposed model intends a) empower young people and prepare for the world of work, b) contributing to recovering and backing on track with the business performance and operations through youth’s labour, and c) contribute to the government and society. The contribution produces a win-win situation for all actors involved. The scheme foresees regular payments for interns for three (3) months and as well their health insurance at work. To produce a win-win situation, through the Banking Association of Kosovo, monthly payment will be directed through the banking accounts and an online financial literacy session will be provided through the online-learning platform. In addition to benefits for young people’s skills building and development in their careers, the paid internship will help young people with income for their families and boost the general consumption. 3) Develop a Reginal GenU action plan With the objective of developing a Regional GenU action plan and sharing of best practices, towards the end of the project, a Regional Workshop will be organized with representatives from UNICEF Country Offices, private sector and government institutions from neighbouring Albania and North Macedonia. This workshop will serve to discuss the prospects and the vision for scale up of the GenU into a regional initiative affecting thousands of young people.
The 9 months implementation of the project will include the first phase of establishment of the GenU platform with its secretariat; second phase of identification of institutions and private firms that will host young people for paid internships, and third and final phase of documentation and development of the Regional Genu initiative action plan. Planned budget for the intervention is 4 000 000 SEK.
Increased inclusion of young people in the labor market has great potential to contribute to rising productivity, not least among SMEs. Increased employment among young people is expected to reduce emigration and gives the opportunity for them to influence the development of their own lives. Thus, the contribution will contribute to the Sweden´s Results Strategy for reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey, 2014-2020, specifically to result area 1 and 2:
1) Enhanced economic integration with the EU and development of market economy 2) Strengthened democracy, greater respect for human rights and a more fully developed state under the rule of law.
The intervention is considered as Sida’s response to Covid-19.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 COVID-19-pandemin har stora ogynnsamma effekter på unga människors liv på Västra Balkan. De övergripande konsekvenserna kopplade till pandemin har påverkat att många unga personer känner sig isolerade, stressade och osäkra kring utbildning, anställning och/eller stabil inkomst samt deras framtid. Nedstängningar av skolor påverkar unga från ogynnsamma förhållanden ytterligare då de erhåller färre utbildningsmöjligheter utanför skolan. Unga är också specifikt utsatta för uppsägning, då de vanligtvis har prekära arbeten, har mindre arbetslivserfarenhet och erhåller kontrakt med sämre skydd för arbetarens rättigheter än äldre anställda. Detta ger skadliga konsekvenser för unga människors psykiska hälsa och välbefinnande, då de försöker adaptera och växa i en osäker framtid, vilket ökar tanken på migration som en lösning.
I denna insats ”Generation Unlimited in Western Balkans”, 2020 – 2021, ämnar UNICEF möta de ungas behov på Västra Balkan kopplat till osäkerheterna kring följderna av COVID-19. Sekretariatet på Generation Unlimited (GenU) har utsett Kosovo som pilotprojekt för projektet på Västra Balkan. GenU är ett globalt multisektoriellt partnerskap för att möta de brådskande behoven av utökad utbildning, träning och anställningsmöjligheter för unga mellan 10 och 24 år. Som pilot för GenU kommer UNICEF:s kontor i Kosovo inneha en ledande och katalyserande roll för andra UNICEF:s kontor på Västra Balkan, att undersöka och utveckla skalbara lösningar för ungas befogenheter och anställningsbarhet. GenU avser att inledas i Västra Balkan med syfte att föra samman UNICEF, den privata sektorn och unga personer.
Sida avser att stödja med en punktinsats under 2020 som ett led i etableringen av GenU på Västra Balkan och ge respons på ungdomars särskilda utsatthet till följd av de ekonomiska konsekvenserna av COVID19. Förväntade resultat av punktinsatsen till ”Generation Unlimited in Western Balkans” är att:
a) Minst 500 unga personer ska ha blivit tränade, certifierade och försedda med möjligheten att genomföra betald praktik i privat sektor, NGOs, FN-organ eller andra organisationer. b) En matchning och en virtuell läroplattform för praktik ska ha utvecklats och försett unga människor med möjlighet till online-lärande. Lärokomponenten ska kombinera den bästa utbildningen och företagspraxis och kompetenser som unga personer behöver detta århundrade. c) Minst 50 företag, NGOs och centrala och lokala institutioner ska vara mobiliserade för erhålla platser för unga praktikanter. d) En handlingsplan för den regionala GenU för Västra Balkan ska ha tagits fram.
Följande projektaktiviteter kommer att genomföras:
1) Identifiera och stärka privata företags och andra institutioner att stå som värdar för unga personer. GenU-plattformen kommer facilitera processen och föra samman privata företagssektorn, civilsamhällesorganisationer, lokala och centrala nivåer av institutioner och andra internationella organisationer att ta emot unga människor som praktikanter som en väg in i arbetslivet. I detta bedöms den privata företagssektorn som den viktigaste mottagaren, med kapacitet och intresse att bidra och ge respons på ungdomars bristande tilltro till framtiden som accentuerats i samband med COVID-19. Enbart under lanseringstiden har redan 22 företag och deras ledning anslutit sig till initiativet genom Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)-nätverket. Deras medlemmar är lokala och internationella aktörer från näringslivet. CSR Nätverket kommer ha den sammankallande rollen för att stärka partnerskapet vad avser att vidga kretsen av anslutna privata företag. 2) Utveckla och sprida en matchningsplattform som kommer möjliggöra 3 månader betald praktik för unga människor. Den föreslagna modellen avser att: a) förbereda ungdomarna för arbetslivet b) bidra till företagens återhämtning med ungdomarnas arbetskraft och c)bidra till samhället i stort och regeringen. Insatsen skapar ett mervärde för samtliga involverade parter. Planen innebär regelbundna utbetalningar till praktikanterna under tre månader samt hälsoförsäkring på arbetet. Utbetalningarna riktas genom bankkonton samt kommer finansiell online-utbildning erbjudas genom den e-baserade läroplattformen. Utöver de fördelar som kompetensutvecklingen ger för deras karriärer, kommer den betalda praktiken hjälpa unga personer med inkomst till deras familjer och öka den generella konsumtionen.
3) Utveckla en regional genomförandeplan för GenU. Med målet att utveckla en genomförandeplan för GenU och dela bästa praxis, mot slutet av projektet, kommer en regional workshop organiseras med representanter från UNICEF:s landskontor, privata sektorn och statliga institutioner från grannländerna Albanien och Nordmakedonien. Workshopen kommer syfta till att diskutera utsikterna och visionen för att skala upp GenU WB till ett regionalt initiativ som påverkar tusentals unga personer.
Implementeringen av projektet kommer under de kommande 9 månaderna inkludera etablerande av en GenU-plattform med sekretariatet i första fasen, identifiera institutioner och privata företag som tar emot unga personer för betalda praktikplatser i fas två och dokumentera och utveckla en regional GenU-initiativhandlingsplan i fas tre. Beräknad budget för insatsen är 4 000 000 SEK.
Insatsen föreslås genomföras som ett led i Sidas rapida respons till COVID-19. Därtill bedöms insatsen som strategisk i förhållande till det nyligen beslutade regionala samarbetet mellan Sida, UNICEF och Naturvårdsverket.
Ökad inklusion av unga på arbetsmarknaden har stora möjligheter att bidra till stigande produktivitet, inte minst bland små och medelstora företag. Ökad sysselsättning bland unga förväntas minska emigration och öka möjligheten för unga att påverka utvecklingen av sina egna liv. Därmed bedöms insatsen också vara relevant för mål 1 och 2 i den regionala strategin, Resultatstrategi för Sveriges reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014 – 2020: 1) Ökad ekonomisk integrering med EU och marknadsekonomisk utveckling. 2) Stärkt demokrati, ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och en mer utvecklad rättsstat
Den föreslagna insatsen ligger också i linje med förväntade prioriteringar i den kommande strategin för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete på Västra Balkan.

Decision on contribution, Generation Unlimited in WB, no. 14336

description.narrative: The project had its formal launch in the beginning of December and has been appreciated by all partners involved and recieved very much attention. The biggest achievement of the project is that it motivated the Governmental sector to taking on responsibility for youth i e the Deputy Prime Minister officielly announced that the Government would support and continue with the internship scheme. Another positive unexpected result of the project is that 35 interns got employed after they conducted their interships. 3 972 persons send the application to 500 internship places that shows the big interest and need for this kind of innitiative. Other results achieved are: •Tri-Lateral Contract with Interns: Reference to the Labor Law and “the Administrative Instruction for settling the easily and forbidden work for the persons under the age of 18 years”, for interns of minor age • Health Insurance Incorporated as part of the agreement •Emphasis on the Safety Regulations, Duties and Responsibilities of the Signing Parties •Agreement with the Raiffeisen Bank for free opening of bank accounts and no maintenance for the banking account of interns •A tailor-made training by the implementing partner on communication, working in the team, HR and best practices for a successful internship journey •CSR Network initiated the process for signing the MoUs with 47 private companies, NGOs, public companies, media, and educational institutions •Established contact with the Employment Agency of Kosovo and partnership with Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports, Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare, ILO and UNDP for developing a sustainable model for internship.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Projektet för stärkt motståndskraft i Albanien (“RESEAL”) har utvecklats som ett heltäckande svar på behoven av att stärka systemen för risk- och katastrofhantering (“DRM”) på alla nivåer efter de förödande effekterna av jordbävningen som drabbade landet den 26 november 2019. Det föreliggande projektet har till syfte att stödja Albaniens regering i dess insatser för att förbättra landets DRM-system. Projektets övergripande mål är att stärka Albaniens DRM-system och att stödja landets insatser för att kunna bli en fullvärdig medlem av EU:s civilskyddsmekanism. Mot bakgrund av den svåra och akuta folkhälsokris som uppkommit till följd av den globala covid-19 pandemin kommer åtgärder relaterade till riskberedskap och riskreducering för biologiska faror att tillhandahållas. Det ovan angivna målet kommer att uppnås genom förbättrad institutionell samordning och samarbete inom DRM-system via vidareutveckling av ramverket för katastrofriskreducering (“DRR”), direktstöd till viktiga DRM-institutioner, med särskild fokus på den nationella myndigheten för civilskydd, samt leverans av kapacitetsuppbyggnad för att stärka nationella, regionala och kommunala institutioners beredskaps- och insatskapacitet. Insatsen omfattar en uppsättning prioriteringar på flera nivåer inom tre områden: 1) förstärkning av DRR-ramverket och kapaciteten på central nivå, 2) uppbyggnad av lokal DRR-kunskap, planerings och organisatoriska kapacitet för förebyggande insatser och beredskap vid katastrofer, och 3) stöd för kritiska behov inom infrastrukturen för katastrofriskhantering.

The Resilience Strengthening in Albania Project (RESEAL) has been developed as a comprehensive response to the needs for strengthening the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) systems at all levels following the devastating effects of the Earthquake that hit the country in November 26th. The present project intends to support the efforts of the Government of Albania for improving the disaster risk management (DRM) system in the country. The overall objective of the project is to strengthen, Albania’s DRM system and support country’s efforts in becoming a fully-fledged member of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. In light of the severe and acute public health emergency due to the COVID-19 global pandemic, measures related to risk preparedness and risk mitigation of biological hazards will be provided. The above objective will be attained through supporting the enhancement of and improvement of institutional coordination and cooperation in DRM system by further developing the DRR framework, providing direct support to key DRM institutions with a particular focus on the National Agency for Civil Protection, and delivering capacity building for strengthening preparedness and response capacities of the national, prefecture and municipal bodies. The intervention contains a multi-level set of priorities around three areas: 1) strengthening the DRR framework and capacities at the central level, 2) building DRR local level knowledge, planning and organizational capacities for prevention and response to disasters, and 3) supporting critical needs for Disaster Risk Reduction infrastructure.
Due to its complexity, the intervention is structured in two major modules. The module I focuses on essential building blocks related to the overall DRR framework including policy, legal and institutional set-up and essential capacities in place, and is designed as a soft assistance. Module II allows for expansion and adoption by especially focusing on securing capital resources for improved monitoring, operation and response for several relevant public institutions ranging from the NACP, prefectural operation rooms and municipal firefighting professionals. Swedish contribution will be focused to Module 1 which is built around three components: Component 1: Strengthening DRM institutional, policy and legal framework in Albania; Component 2: Strengthening disaster preparedness capacities at all levels; Component 3: Sustain Albania’s Regional & International Cooperation. Sweden’s financial contribution, like that of the other donors, will be disbursed into the trust fund andadministered from UNDP with the GoA through the Ministry of Defense and the national Civil Protection Agency Agency (NCPA), being in the lead for activity planning and inter-institutional coordination.

The present project intends to support the efforts of the Government of Albania for improving the disaster risk management (DRM) system in the country. The overall objective of the project is to strengthen, Albania’s DRM system and support country’s efforts in becoming a fully-fledged member of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. The project is also in line with promoting the implementation of Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction (SFDRR) and is developed based on the Albania earthquake PDNA recommendations. Also, in light of the severe and acute public health emergency due to the COVID-19 global pandemic, measures related to risk preparedness and risk mitigation of biological hazards will be provided. The above objective will be attained through supporting the enhancement of institutional coordination and cooperation in DRM system by further developing the DRR framework, providing direct support to key DRM institutions with a particular focus on the National Agency for Civil Protection, and delivering capacity building for strengthening preparedness and response capacities of the national, prefecture and municipal bodies. The project will, in parallel, initiate the Capacity Development Process for the Disaster Risk Management System in Albania, which is indispensable for risk-informed development effectiveness and the achievement of nationally and internationally agreed development targets, and assist prefecture and municipal levels through supporting institutional building as per the legal requirements and the exercises of local risk assessment, local DRR strategies and Emergency Plans. One key ingredient of the DRR legal framework and essential element for building-back-better (BBB) during recovery is the update of the Building Codes, an area within the focus of the proposed intervention. The project will support, during its entire duration, opportunities for capacity building and regional exchanges in order to complement national efforts for reducing risk and contributing to Albania’s aspiration to meet the criteria for joining the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. Due to its complexity, the intervention is structured in two major modules, in line with the PDNA priorities. The module I focuses on essential building blocks related to the overall DRR framework including policy, legal and institutional set-up and essential capacities in place, and is designed as a soft assistance. Module II allows for expansion and adoption by especially focusing on securing capital resources for improved monitoring, operation and response for several relevant public institutions ranging from the NACP, prefectural operation rooms and municipal firefighting professionals. The second module is the most demanding in terms of resources and, therefore, it will largely depend on resource availability. However, being mostly about procurement of goods, it will not require additional human resources and operational costs, but will rely on the project arrangements, resources and operational costs built within the first module. The intervention is built around three components: Component 1: Strengthening DRM institutional, policy and legal framework in Albania; Component 2: Strengthening disaster preparedness capacities at all levels; Component 3: Sustain Albania’s Regional & International Cooperation. In order to secure that the allocated funding is used for the most crucial and high priority actions, UNDP and GoA have developed a Work Plan for the project based only on resources to be provided by UNDP Albania and Sweden. All the activities and planned results belong to module 1 and the RESEAL Work Plan document will be the guiding tool for the implementation of the intervention.

description.narrative: Purpose of contribution"The guaranty provided under the terms and conditions of the Agreement (the “Guaranty”) is intended to strengthen the Guaranteed Party’s ability to provide loans to productive MSME’s in Georgia in a broad array of sectors, including but not limited to creative industry (including artisans and film), light manufacturing, tourism, information communications technology, e-commerce, agriculture, and logistics, with a focus on underserved borrower groups, including women, start-ups and those outside of the major urban centers. The loans will assist MSMEs in Georgia to weather the current COVID related economic crises, thereby stimulating economic growth. No less than twenty percent (20%) of the total number of Qualifying Loans must be made to Qualifying Borrowers located outside of the major cities of Tbilisi, Batumi and Kutaisi. No less than thirty percent (30%) of the total number of Qualifying Loans must be made to Qualifying Borrowers who [are women or that are] women-managed MSMEs or NGOs.

Sida and United States International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) /United States Agency for International Development (USAID) implements a co-guarantee partnership in the support of JSC MFO Crystal (Crystal) in Georgia. The contribution is a loan portfolio guarantee for the period of 2020-2028.
The intervention aims at strengthening JSC MFO Crystal's ability to provide loans to productive MSME’s in Georgia in a broad array of sectors, including but not limited to creative industry (including artisans and film), light manufacturing, tourism, information communications technology, e-commerce, agriculture, and logistics, with a focus on underserved borrower groups, including women (not less than 30 % of disbursements under the guarantee), start-ups and those outside of the major urban centers (not less than 20 % of disbursements under the guarantee). The loans will assist MSMEs in Georgia to weather the current COVID related economic crises, thereby stimulating economic growth.
Total disbursed amount under the contribution is US$15,000,000 (The maximum cumulative amount of all loan disbursements). The intervention is a non-revolving guarantee with loan portfolio structure where the risk is shared equally between Sida (25 %) and USAID (25 %) pari passu, and the remaining risk is carried by the Guarantee Party, JSC MFO Crystal. The guaranteed amount is US$7,500,000 USD (Sida US$3,750,000 and USAID US$3,750,000).

Sida och United States International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) /United States Agency for International Development (USAID) genomför tillsammans en samgaranti för att stöjda JSC MFO Crystal (Crystal) i Georgien. Insatsen är en låneportföljgaranti för perioden 2020-2028.
Insatsen syftar till att stärka JSC MFO Crystal's förmåga att utge lån till produktiva MSMEs i Georgien mot en brett spektrum av sektorer inkluderande men inte begränsat till kreativ industri (inkluderande hantverk och film), lätt tillverkning, turism, ICT, e-handel, jordbruk, och logistik med ett fokus på grupperingar som har sämre tillgång till lån, inkluderande kvinnor (inte mindre än 30 % av utbetalning under garantin), startups och låntagare utanför huvudsakliga urbana områden (inte mindre än 20 % av utbetalningar under garantin). Lånen syftar till att hjäpa MSMEs i Georgien att hantera den pågående COVID-relaterade ekonomiska krisen, och därmed stimulera ekonomisk tillväxt.
Total utlåning under garantin är 15 000 000 USD (maximalt kumulativt belopp av lån under garantin). Insatsen är icke-revolverande med en låneportföljstruktur där risken delas lika mellan Sida (25%) och USAID (25%) pari passu, och den återstående delen bärs av garantitagaren, JSC MFO Crystal. Garanterat belopp är 7 500 000 USD (Sida 3 750 000 USD och USAID 3 750 000 USD)

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
