description.narrative:
NALED har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering med 14 394 920 kronor för att genomföra projektet "Offentlig upphandling för ekonomisk tillväxt" i Serbien under perioden 2021-2022. Insatsens totala budget är 14 394 920 kronor varav 100% av budgeten kommer från Sida. Vidareförmedling av medel ska inte förekomma i projektet.
NALED är en oberoende icke-vinstdrivande och opolitisk förening med över 300 olika medlemmar i form av företag, kommuner och olika civilsamhälles organisationer som arbetar tillsammans för att skapa bättre förutsättningar för att leva och arbeta i Serbien. NALED ingår även i ett partnernätverk som involverar mer än 100 olika statliga institutioner och internationella organisationer och har en egen pool av experter som gör det möjligt för organisationen att erbjuda kvalificerade program för kapacitetsuppbyggnad och utbildningar till offentlig sektor i Serbien inom en rad områden till en konkurrenskraftig kostnad. Sammantaget har NALED bedömts ha relevant teknisk kompetens och kapacitet att på ett effektivt sätt samarbeta med ett brett spektrum av aktörer för att uppnå relevanta och hållbara resultat. Eftersom de är en ny partner till Sida planeras dock en effektivitetsrevision genomföras någon gång under den tid projektet pågår med huvudfokus på frågor som avser intern styrning och kontroll.
Det föreslagna projektet är mångfacetterat och involverar ett antal parallella kompletterande processer inom den serbiska EU närmandeprocessen. Huvudinriktningen är reformer avseende en mer effektiv offentlig förvaltning, minskad korruption och en anpassning till EU:s inre marknad genom förbättrade offentliga upphandlingar.
Det föreslagna projektet innehåller ett detaljerat resultatramverk och de föreslagna resultatområdena har valts ut på grund av deras relevans och genomförbarhet. Projektet innehåller även komponenter avseende bl a ökad användning av miljökrav och sociala krav (inklusive jämställdhet) i offentlig upphandling i Serbien samt ökad användning av kriteriet ekonomiskt mest fördelaktigt anbud vid tilldelning av kontrakt vilket i sin tur förväntas bidra till bättre användning av offentliga medel och en långsiktigt mera hållbar ekonomisk utveckling i landet.
Bidraget är relevant eftersom det följer nationellt fastställda prioriteringar och är i linje med Serbiens och Sveriges strategiska mål. Möjligheterna att nå avsedda resultat ökas genom en nära koppling till planerade och pågående institutionella reformer inom den serbiska offentliga förvaltningen inklusive en ökad grad av digitalisering.
Budgeten bedöms vara rimlig i förhållande till mål och förväntade resultat. Budgeten är uppdelad i två delar: 1) Programförvaltning och aktivitetskostnader och 2) Programdriftskostnader. Enligt revisionsrapporten för 2019 uppgick NALED:s inkomst från olika bidrag till 133 394 miljoner dinarer (ungefär 12 MSEK) och det aktuella bidraget från Sida skulle då motsvara 39% av det totala beloppet för 2021 respektive 36% för 2022 under nuvarande förutsättningar.
Det finns en tydlig uppdelning mellan avgifter och ersättningsgilla kostnader och förteckningar används för att koppla budgetposter med resultatområden i resultatramverket. Sammantaget motsvarar programförvaltningskostnader 26.9% av den totala budgeten. Kostnaderna för konsultarvoden och aktiviteter uppgår till 64.7% den totala budgeten, vilket är rimligt i ett program av denna komplexitet. Programdriftskostnader uppgår till 8.9% av den totala budgeten och inkluderar kostnaderna för hyran, telefon, kontorsmateriel, revision, bankkostnader och bokföring. Det finns ingen "overhead" angiven i budgeten.
Riskerna för effektiviteten och genomförbarheten av projektet har bedömts, dokumenterats och sammanfattats i ett riskanalysregister. Riskerna har bedömts i förhållande till de förväntade resultat och hänsyn har tagits till principerna för biståndseffektivitet. De största riskerna med detta projekt avser konsekvenser av Covid-19 pandemin för aktiviteter, bristande politisk vilja för faktisk implementering av reformer, otillräckligt ägande och oklara ansvarsområden hos projektpartners (inklusive brist på personal) samt otillräcklig samordning med andra projekt och mellan olika aktörer involverade i projektet. Sammantaget bedöms en majoritet av identifierade risker som låg och lämpliga åtgärder har identifierats för att hantera dessa risker. Avtalade riskhanteringsåtgärder genomförs inom den övergripande ramen för uppföljning samt genom dialog och formell rapportering.
Dialogfrågor har identifierats och de viktigaste frågorna att följa upp i dialogen kommer att vara förstärkning av systemet för uppföljning av signaler om oegentligheter, förbättrad intern övervakning och rapportering om genomförandet av interna förvaltnings- och kontrollförfaranden samt förstärkning av riskanalysprocessen inom organisationen.
Sidas avtalsmall för bidrag till icke-statliga organisationer kan användas utan avvikelser.

NALED has submitted an application to Sida to support the implementation of the project "Public Procurement for Economic Growth" in Serbia during the period 2021-2022 in the amount of SEK 14,394,920. The total budget of the contribution is SEK 14,394,920 and 100% of the budget comes from Sida. There will be no forwarding of funds in the project.
NALED is an independent, non-profit and non-partisan association of more than 300 members, including businesses, local governments and civil society organizations, which work together on creating favorable conditions for living and working in Serbia. NALED is also a part of a partner network involving more than 100 state institutions and international organizations and it has its own pool of experts that enables which enables them to provide capacity building programs and trainings for public sector in Serbia in a number of areas at a competitive cost. Overall, NALED has been assessed to be in the possession of relevant technical expertise and capacity to effectively collaborate with a wide range of stakeholders to achieve relevant and sustainable results. However, since they are a new partner to Sida, an efficiency audit will be performed at one point during the implementation with a main focus on issues related to governance and internal control.
This is a multifaceted project that involves a number of parallel complementary processes within the broader EU integration agenda. The main focus is on reforms towards a more efficient public administration, reduced corruption and adaptation to the EU internal market through improved public procurement.
The proposed project contains a detailed results framework and the proposed result areas have been selected due to their relevance and feasibility. The project also includes components regarding, among other things, the increased use of environmental and social requirements (including gender equality) in public procurement in Serbia as well as the increased use of the most economically advantageous criterion in the award of contracts, which is expected to contribute to better use of public funds and long-term more sustainable economic development in the country.
The contribution is relevant, as it follows the nationally set priorities and is in line with Serbia's and Sweden's strategic goals. Opportunities to achieve intended results are increased through a close link with planned and ongoing institutional reforms in the Serbian public administration, including an increased level of digitization.
The budget is assessed to be reasonable in relation to expected results. The budget is divided into two parts: Program Management and Activity Costs and Program Operational Costs. According to the 2019 audit report, NALED's income from various contributions amounted to 133,394 million dinars (approximately SEK 12 million) and the current contribution from Sida would correspond to 39% of the total amount for 2021 and 36% for 2022 if observed under the same conditions.
There is a clear division between fees and reimbursables and indices are used to link budget items with results areas in the results framework. Program Management costs represent 26.9% of the total budget. The cost of consultancy fees and activities amount to 64.7% of the total budget, which is reasonable in a program of this complexity. Program Operational Costs amount to 8.9% of the total budget and include the cost of rent, telephone, office supplies, auditing, bank costs and accounting. There is no overhead cost in the budget.
The risks to the efficiency and feasibility of the project have been assessed, documented and summarized in a risk analysis register. The main risks of this project relate to the consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic on activities, lack of political will for the actual implementation of reforms, insufficient ownership and unclear responsibilities of project partners (including lack of staff) and insufficient coordination with other projects and between various actors involved in the project. Overall, a majority of identified risks are considered to be low and appropriate measures have been identified to manage these risks. Agreed risk management measures will be implemented within the overall framework for follow-up and through dialogue and formal reporting.
Dialogue issues have been identified and the most important issues to follow up in the dialogue will be the strengthening of the system for following up on signals on irregularities, improved internal monitoring and reporting on the implementation of internal management and control procedures and strengthening the risk analysis process within the organization.
Sida's agreement template for grants to non-governmental organizations can be used without deviations.

The overall objective is organized in four items: 1) To improve the impact of public spending on competition and market development, 2) To improve the cost-effectiveness (quality/price ratio) and impact of public spending on environment and social inclusiveness, 3) To contribute to decrease of corruption and irregularities in public procurement, as well as building trust in the public procurement system and 4) To contribute to Covid-19 recovery via more efficient public spending. The overall objectives are expected to be reached by targeting the following specific objectives, structured as the three project components/result areas: 1) To contribute to improved implementation of the new Law on Public Procurement (legal and strategic framework) by strengthening the capacities of purchasers (institutions) and bidders (companies), 2) To improve the transparency and efficiency of the system for planning and monitoring of public procurement by improving and promoting the use of digital solutions, 3) To improve the oversight and enforcement of rights in public procurement and strengthen the role of civil society and general public.

title.narrative: COVID-19 IOM 2020 COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Southern and Horn of Africa
COVID-19 IOM 2020 COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Southern and Horn of Africa

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 The International Organization for Migration (IOM) has applied to Sida for funds of SEK 20 044 000 to carry out the "COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Southern and Horn of Africa Project” over a period of six months, July 2020 to January 2021.
The intervention aims to contribute to a well-coordinated, informed, and timely response to COVID-19 in two Regional Economic Communities (RECs) of the African Union – namely Intergovernmental Authority for Development (IGAD) and Southern African Development Community (SADC) - in line with the Africa Joint Response to COVID-19, through mobility tracking systems and preparedness and response efforts to reduce associated morbidity and mortality.
IOM is proposing to strengthen the support provided to Member States along the following 2 pillars of collaboration: 1) Information Management 2) Strengthened Member State Capacity
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) will be the implementer of the project in collaboration with national governments of Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Tanzania and Mozambique.
The intervention’s total budget is 20 044 000 SEK.
Disbursement of the total amount will be made upon signing of the agreement since the project has a duration of only six months and because of the emergency nature of the intervention.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 IOM har ansökt om medel från Sida för att genomföra projektet "COVID-19 Preparedness and Response in Southern and Horn of Africa” under sexmånadersperioden juli 2020 till januari 2021.
Insatsens avsikt är att bidra till en väl samordnad och i tid läglig respons på covid-19 pandemin inom två av den Afrikanska unionens regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper (RECs), nämligen Intergovernmental Authority for Development (IGAD) och Southern African Development Community (SADC), vilket är i linje med den gemensamma Afrikanska responsen på covid-19 - att genom mobilitetsspårningssystem och beredskaps- och responsinsatser minska covid-19 relaterade sjukdomar och dödlighet.
IOM föreslår att stödet skall användas för att stärka medlemsländernas informationshantering och kapacitet att hantera krisen.
Insatsen skall genomföras under IOMs ledning i samarbete med Djiboutis, Etiopiens, Kenyas, Tanzanias, Malawis och Mocambiques regeringar.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen uppgår till 20 044 000 kronor.
Utbetalning av beloppet i sin helhet kommer göras vid undertecknandet av avtalet pga. insatsens brådskande natur samt att insatsens aktivitetsperiod endast pågår under 6 månader.

The overall objective of the proposed project is to contribute to a well-coordinated, informed, and timely response to COVID-19 in two Regional Economic Communities (RECs) of the African Union – namely Intergovernmental Authority for Development (IGAD) and Southern African Development Community (SADC) and in line with the Africa Joint Response to COVID-19 – through mobility tracking systems and preparedness and response efforts to reduce associated morbidity and mortality. IOM is proposing to strengthen the support provided to Member States along 2 pillars of collaboration: 1) Information Management: Stakeholders have access to timely, context-specific, and accurate information to strengthen outbreak analysis, projection, and response. 2) Strengthened Member State Capacity: Member States’ human mobility incorporated COVID-19 preparedness and response capacity is strengthened.

tag.narrative: 3.d - Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
3.d - Stärka alla länders, i synnerhet utvecklingsländernas, kapacitet när det gäller tidig varning, riskreducering och hantering av nationella och globala hälsorisker.

title.narrative: COVID-19 WHO AFRO COVID-19 implications on SRHR and mitigating risk of system collapse
COVID-19 WHO AFRO Covid-19 påverkan på SRHR och motverka risk för systemkollaps

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 WHO AFRO has applied to Sweden for funding of 80 million SEK to carry out the " Country Level AFRO Reform (DCL): From COVID to HEALTH), which is divided into two pillars. Pillar 1: COVID-19 implications on essential health service delivery (i.e., SRHR) and mitigating the risk of system collapse" and pillar two “Coordinated Strategic and Policy Support for Structural and Functional Transformation of WHO Country Offices.” The programme will be implemented between 1 July 2020 and 31 December 2021. Sida will contribute 30 Million SEK to pillar one and the Ministry for Foreign Affairs (MFA) will contribute 50 million SEK to pillar two.
The funding will be used to strengthen and amplify the convening power, influence, and mandate of the WHO/AFRO to offer quality and timely technical support to the focus countries. More specifically, this Grant will allow WHO/AFRO to support the focus countries in achieving the following outcomes:
1. Maintained continuity of essential high-quality SRHR information and services through a health system approach, including preventing and responding to sexual and gender-based violence 2. Increased access to a wider range of contraceptive methods (expanded method mix) through Task Sharing and self-care interventions 3. Strengthened monitoring system for tracking progress in SRHR/Family Planning.
This investment will enable WHO-AFRO to contribute to components of its Transformation Agenda 2015-2020—pro-results values, smart technical focus; responsive strategic operations; and effective communication and partnerships in the SRHR workspace. It will also contribute to the Regional WHO transformation aiming at understanding the country’s priorities as well as the type and level of support required and align WHO country presence to the Member States and partner expectations (linked to Pillar II).
WHO AFRO will implement the contribution in close coronation with 2Gether4SRHR (ID: 10596), in particular the agreement amended (ZAM-DC19/2020). The total budget of the contribution is 80 Million SEK, where Sida contributes 30 MSEK and the Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs 50 MSEK (Decision UD2020/08919/IU, UD2020/01985/FN) .
The contribution is in line with the Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Konsekvenserna av covid-19 pandemin för låg- och medelinkomstländer riskerar bli katastrofala både vad gäller hälsoutfall och för den sociala och ekonomiska utvecklingen. I slutet av juni 2020 var antalet bekräftade fall av covid-19, som orsakas av coronavirus (SARS CoV-2), drygt 8,8 miljoner och 465 000 personer har avlidit. Afrika har än så länge relativt få fall, men WHO:s Regionkontor för Afrika (AFRO) uppskattar att 22 procent av befolkningen på den afrikanska kontinenten kommer att smittas under pandemins första år, vilket kan komma att resultera i 190 000 dödsfall. The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) har nyligen publicerat en analys som visar att covid-19 Afrikas pandemi har haft samma utveckling under de första 150 dagarna som de kontinenter som drabbats tidigare.
Utöver direkta hälsokonsekvenserna av covid-19 visar ett antal prognoser att krishanteringen kan komma att tränga undan grundläggande hälso- och sjukvårdsinsatser, inklusive sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR). Dessutom riskerar covid-19 responsen att finansiera punktinsatser istället för att beakta helhetsbehov och bygga motståndskraftiga system för att möjliggöra återhämtning. Erfarenhet från Ebola-epidemin visade att gravida kvinnors tillgång till mödrahälsovård minskade med förhöjd mödradödlighet som konsekvens. Tidiga uppgifter från covid-19 drabbade länder i regionen visar till exempel en ökning med 30% i antalet ärenden om könsrelaterat våld. Nyckelgrupper är särskilt sårbara på grund av minskat försörjning, stigma och diskriminering. Sida ser därmed en stor risk resultaten i Sveriges regionala SRHR strategi riskerar att påverkas negativt, vilket föranlett behovet av att stödja den kontinentala covid-19 responsen, med fokus på de indirekta effekterna av pandemin på SRHR.
Den 22 februari 2020 hölls ett krismöte med alla Afrikas 55 hälsoministrar/ hälsoministerier vilket resulterade i en kontinental strategi mot covid-19. Sydafrikas president, i egenskap av ordförande för Afrikanska Unionen, godkände strategin tillsammans med den byrå som bistår ordföranden, för närvarande presidenterna från Mali, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Egypten och Kenya. Den kontinentala covid-19 strategin Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak har två övergripande mål: 1) att förebygga svår sjukdom och död av coronavirusinfektion i medlemsländer och 2) att minimera sociala och ekonomiska konsekvenser av covid-19 utbrottet
Målsättningarna ska uppnås via två huvudsakliga arbetsspår: att samordna covid-19 responsen mellan medlemsländer, AU:s organ och WHO, och andra partners för att säkerställa synergier och att minska risker för dubbelarbete samt genom att främja evidensbaserade folkhälsostrategier för övervakning (surveillance), förebyggande arbete, diagnos, behandling och kontroll av covid-19.
Strategin implementeras genom Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), där Africa CDC, FN och AU:s medlemsländer leder arbetsgrupper, och genom Africa CDC’s Incident Management System (IMS). Ett antal partners, både FN och ickestatliga aktörer, bidrar också till att implementera strategin. Dessa implementerande partners finansieras antingen direkt av biståndsgivare som finansierar kompletterande insatser, eller via Africa CDC som sedan vidareförmedlar medel till implementerande partners. Ett tillägg finns även till strategin, AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19- Continental Strategy, som inkluderar specifik referens till att säkerställa tillgång till grundläggande hälsosjukvård, inklusive mödrabarnhälsovård under covid-19 pandemin.
Sida kommer att bidra till Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak genom två nya insatser och en avtalsändring av en pågående insats, 2Gether4SRHR (insats ID: 10596, beslutsnummer ZAM-DC19/2020). De två nya insatserna är till Africa CDC om SEK 20 000 000 och till WHO AFRO om SEK 30 000 000. Sida ser på insatserna som tre delar av ett sammanhållet stöd i linje med ovan nämnda strategi, dvs Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak.
WHO AFRO har sökt om finansiering för programmet Country Level AFRO Reform (DCL): From COVID to HEALTH (2020–2021), som är uppdelat på två pelare. Pelare ett: COVID-19 implications on essential health service delivery (i.e., SRHR) and mitigating the risk of system collapse och pelare två: Coordinated Strategic and Policy Support for Structural and Functional Transformation of WHO Country Offices under perioden 1 juli 2020 till 31 december 2021. Sida kommer att finanserna pelare ett med 30 miljoner SEK och UD finansiera pelare två med 50 Miljoner SEK (Beslut UD2020/08919/IU, UD2020/01985/FN). Den totala volymen är 80 miljoner SEK. Insatsen finansieras via en s.k. pooled fund som administreras av WHO AFRO, som är avtalspart. Aktiviteterna under pelare ett kommer att genomföras inom WHO AFRO regionen, med följande fokusländer: Sierra Leone, Kenya, Burkina Faso, Kamerun, Nigeria, Centralafrikanska Republiken och Demokratiska Republiken Kongo och genom stärkt kapacitet för samordning på det WHO:s regionala kontor för AFRO-regionen i Brazzaville.

The objectives of the intervention have not been changed. This intervention supports the WHO AFRO implementation of the Country Level AFRO Reform (DCL): From COVID to HEALTH, "Pillar 1: COVID-19 implications on essential health service delivery (i.e., SRHR) and mitigating the risk of system collapse". The initiative will strengthen and amplify the convening power, influence, and mandate of the WHO AFRO to offer quality and timely technical support to focus countries, in order to achieve the following outcomes: 1. Maintained continuity of essential high-quality SRHR information and services through a health system approach, including preventing and responding to sexual and gender-based violence 2. Increased access to a wider range of contraceptive methods (expanded method mix) through Task Sharing and self-care interventions 3. Strengthened monitoring system for tracking progress in SRHR/Family Planning. Additional funding to Pillar 2 “Coordinated Strategic and Policy Support for Structural and Functional Transformation of WHO Country Offices” is channeled trough the Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs.

participating-org.narrative: World Health Organisation - core voluntary contributions account

sector.narrative: Basic Health Care Services in Emergencies

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

description.narrative: NRC is Norway’s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida's Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC's capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida's humanitarian unit's annual budget appropriation which is substantial. The objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: "To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors." It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. NRC’s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. Sida's Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC's method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). More specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras/El Salvador/Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. As an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: 26% for Shelter and settlements, 20% for Education, 17% for Livelihoods and Food Security, 14% for ICLA, 9% for WASH, 3% for Camp Management and 11% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. The good scores of NRC in ITAD's evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. Describing NRC's activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC's work. SHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC's expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in protracted displacement situations. LIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON/Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten livelihoods and individuals' and households' abilities to earn a living. ICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one's rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC's lawyers. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to people to claim and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face particular obstacles in accessing their rights. EDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. CAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. WASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L/person/day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of infrastructre for water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. Sida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida's funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. RRM Allocation 2021 Included in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC's capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida's funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. Method- and capacity-building projects Included in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. - Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the ‘Safe Programming’ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC's operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in 'refugee-like' situations. - Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC's ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. - Sida's support to NRC's CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian/development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. - NRC’s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida's humanitarian unit and Sida's unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida's Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. - NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. NRC's active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida's support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC's commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. - Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida's humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution.

Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrådet (NRC) - har ansökt om ett förnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC har dessutom ansökt om finansiering på 364,5 miljoner SEK för att genomföra humanitära insatser i 26 humanitära krisområden under 2021: Afghanistan, Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Eritrea, Etiopien, Iran, Irak, Jordanien, Kenya, Libanon, Libyen, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexiko, Palestina, Somalia, Sydsudan, Sudan, Tanzania / Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela och Jemen. Ansökan inkluderar även 40 miljoner kronor för den humanitära snabbmekanismen (RRM) och 20 miljoner kronor i stöd till sju projekt för metodstöd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och samordning.
NRC:s mål är att i krissituationer skydda fördrivna och utsatta människor, värna deras rättigheter och bistå med assistans för att möta deras omedelbara humanitära behov, förhindra ytterligare fördrivning, samt bidra till hållbara lösningar. Dessutom tillhandahåller NRC expertis som en strategisk partner för det humanitära systemet och dess olika aktörer. NRC bedriver också principbaserat och tydligt påverkanarbete för att utöva inflytande på beslutsfattare. NRC planerar att under 2021 bistå 7,263,000 personer med humanitära behov.
NRC bygger sina program med människor i centrum, och med särskild inriktning på personer som har tvingats på flykt. Det är en rättighetsbaserad organisation som verkar för att ge skydd åt de mest utsatta och sårbara och hjälpa dem att återuppbygga sina liv. NRC arbetar därför alltid för hållbara lösningar när de genomför humanitära projekt och program. Organisationen integrerar även humanitär medling och förhandling mellan olika parter i samhället i sina program och på så sätt kan organisationen även bidra till en fredliga lösningar på lånvariga konflikter. NRC:s programmering stävar efter att stärka kopplingar mellan humanitärt bistånd, utveckling och fred.
NRC kommer i huvudsak att genomföra insatsen på egen hand, genom organisationens 7 700 anställda och 7 000 volontärer som mobilisera i de områdena där insatsen genomförs.
Den aktuella budgeten för NRC:s hela humanitära program 2021 uppgår till 4 263 200 000 NOK, varav Sidas del för närvarande utgör ca 8%. Givare, som det norska utrikesministeriet, GD ECHO, UNHCR, etc. bidrar med större volymer och ytterligare ett tiotal andra givare har ingått avtal med NRC. Sida ger NRC möjligheten att nyttja resurser flexibelt inom varje enskilt landprogram, (enligt så kallad Programme-Based Approach – PBA)
Humanitär-Utveckling-Fred Nexus NRC bidrar i hög grad till arbetet för att sammankoppla humanitärt bistånd med freds- och utvecklingsinsatser. Organisationens strävan att effektivisera biståndet genom katalytiskt stöd till samordning och kapacitetsbyggande insatser bidrar till denna ansats. I samarbetet med andra organisationer möjliggör och bidrar NRC:s verksamhet och påverkansarbete till att stärka hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och människor som har blivit tvångsfördrivna och bidrar därmed till att på sikt minska de humanitära behoven. Även krisdrabbade människors möjligheter till självförsörjning prioriteras. NRC:s analyskapacitet är en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomförs av NRC:s internationella center för övervakning av tvångsförflyttning (IDMC) är av stor vikt för dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfölj som Sida finansierar avser länder där Sverige även bedriver utvecklingssamarbete vilket öppnar för möjligheter till synergier med humanitärt bistånd.

The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) has applied for a renewed strategic partnership with Sida during 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out “the Humanitarian Programme for 2021” in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination.
The objectives of NRC’s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRC's principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021.
NRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRC's programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus.
NRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.
The intervention’s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sida’s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR, etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach – PBA).
Humanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus NRC's catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRC's advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRC's analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRC's portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Sweden's development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: NRC is Norway’s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida's Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC's capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida's humanitarian unit's annual budget appropriation which is substantial. The objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: "To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors." It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. NRC’s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. Sida's Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC's method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). More specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras/El Salvador/Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. As an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: 26% for Shelter and settlements, 20% for Education, 17% for Livelihoods and Food Security, 14% for ICLA, 9% for WASH, 3% for Camp Management and 11% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. The good scores of NRC in ITAD's evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. Describing NRC's activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC's work. SHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC's expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in protracted displacement situations. LIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON/Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten livelihoods and individuals' and households' abilities to earn a living. ICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one's rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC's lawyers. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to people to claim and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face particular obstacles in accessing their rights. EDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. CAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. WASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L/person/day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: Provision of infrastructre for water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. Sida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida's funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. RRM Allocation 2021 Included in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC's capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida's funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the ‘Safe Programming’ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC's operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in 'refugee-like' situations. - Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. Organisationen integrerar även humanitär medling och förhandling mellan olika parter i samhället i sina program och på så sätt kan organisationen även bidra till en fredliga lösningar på lånvariga konflikter. NRC:s programmering stävar efter att stärka kopplingar mellan humanitärt bistånd, utveckling och fred.
NRC kommer i huvudsak att genomföra insatsen på egen hand, genom organisationens 7 700 anställda och 7 000 volontärer som mobilisera i de områdena där insatsen genomförs.
Den aktuella budgeten för NRC:s hela humanitära program 2021 uppgår till 4 263 200 000 NOK, varav Sidas del för närvarande utgör ca 8%. Givare, som det norska utrikesministeriet, GD ECHO, UNHCR, etc. bidrar med större volymer och ytterligare ett tiotal andra givare har ingått avtal med NRC. Sida ger NRC möjligheten att nyttja resurser flexibelt inom varje enskilt landprogram, (enligt så kallad Programme-Based Approach – PBA)
Humanitär-Utveckling-Fred Nexus NRC bidrar i hög grad till arbetet för att sammankoppla humanitärt bistånd med freds- och utvecklingsinsatser. Organisationens strävan att effektivisera biståndet genom katalytiskt stöd till samordning och kapacitetsbyggande insatser bidrar till denna ansats. I samarbetet med andra organisationer möjliggör och bidrar NRC:s verksamhet och påverkansarbete till att stärka hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och människor som har blivit tvångsfördrivna och bidrar därmed till att på sikt minska de humanitära behoven. Även krisdrabbade människors möjligheter till självförsörjning prioriteras. NRC:s analyskapacitet är en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomförs av NRC:s internationella center för övervakning av tvångsförflyttning (IDMC) är av stor vikt för dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfölj som Sida finansierar avser länder där Sverige även bedriver utvecklingssamarbete vilket öppnar för möjligheter till synergier med humanitärt bistånd.

The Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) has applied for a renewed strategic partnership with Sida during 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out “the Humanitarian Programme for 2021” in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania/Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination.
The objectives of NRC’s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRC's principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021.
NRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRC's programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus.
NRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.
The intervention’s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sida’s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR, etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach – PBA).
Humanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus NRC's catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRC's advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRC's analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRC's portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Sweden's development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.
